l3ZKUqUguSlG9PH0xRC8dw.review_text: Came here for a light dinner after the Fillmore Jazz Festival last weekend. I have to say I really enjoyed the visit. First off, I made a reservation through yelp. Easy, simple, and I got the time I wanted. We even arrived a half an hour early and they seated us without a wait!  I like the feel of this place. Lots of dark wood and splashes of green. Definitely felt Zen-influenced.  We ordered a few items: the hawaiian poke salad, a california roll, a yellowtail dish, and a boiled egg cooked inside of a fried pumpkin bread. All of it was delicious. I really liked how spicy the poke salad was. I'm not a general fan of seafood, but I really enjoyed the salad. The California roll was also really delicious; no imitation crab here! The yellowtail was alright; once again, this is just my palate not being so favorable to seafood. My favorite though was the egg in fried pumpkin bread. I could eat that over and over again!  We also got a couple of drinks: a blood orange chuhai and a green tea chuhai. Strong and flavorful.  Only complaint was that our waitress wasn't around all that often; it was hard to flag her down.  I'd definitely come back though!

9sWf1QjQbmAHZMwRsCI6vg.review_text: I wasn't very familiar with the Izakaya tradition before eating here, so I'd return with a large group after work for drinks instead of choosing it for date night. I really enjoyed the octopus balls and thought the ramen was great since it wasn't too salty (and had lots of vegetables!) but I wasn't blown away by any of the flavors. We tried both the chicken and the pork skewers and could barely taste a difference between the two dishes.  The wakame salad was tasty, but I wish there was more of it... the clump of seaweed looked a little lonely in the middle of the big bowl on top of a couple of thin tomato slices.   I'd request the Tatami area next time- and do a little research on the food before hand.

sht0n7Up25_gkrIYbD36jQ.review_text: Very rarely will you find a Japanese restaurant that does everything right. Izakaya Hashibiro Kou is a total game-changer. They've successfully transformed a traditional Izakaya into a modern, hip, and fun dining experience by offering Japanese-style tapas infused with Asian influences in a cozy lounge-like atmosphere. Their extensive menu ranges from yakitori to fresh-cut sashimi to ramen to grilled and fried items. In my opinion, it's the best way to eat. Because duh, you get to share everything- which means you get bites of everything. It's a win-win. And lemme tell yah, their drink menu is just as impressive: Sapporo on tap, wine, cocktails and freshly-squeezed juices. They also have an extensive sake list to please all audiences. So. If you're looking for a fun night out with a group of friends OR just a high- energy date night atmosphere, then this is your place. + KOU Sashimi ($18)- You get a total of 9 pieces of fresh cut sashimi; salmon, hawaiian big eye tuna, and yellowtail (no substitution). Overall, I was very impressed with the quality of their fish (being that it's not a true sushi restaurant). + Gindara Misozuke ($11)-  Miso marinated black cod. This is one of my favorite things here. You get a buttery piece of seared black cod that melts with each bite you take. It's the only dish where I secretly wish I wasn't sharing with everyone (sshhhhh). + Tofu Temptation ($7)- The soft tofu arrives beautifully presented with three variations: topped with Korean style mentaiko, uni, and oshinko. This is a great appetizer to get your taste buds flowing for the next couple of dishes. + The seafood ramen is just ridiculous. Like, I can't believe how much I love this bowl of ramen. It has just the right amount of spiciness (jalapeño) so that it doesn't take away the taste of the broth. The noodles were cooked to perfection. And you get a good variety of seafood options (shrimp, mussels, octopus, etc). Get it, and you wont be sorry. + Uni ($10)- sea urchin from Santa Barbara They give you hugeeee chunks of uni where it's practically falling over the sides. The uni was pretty good for an Izakaya restaurant (b/c I definitely didn't expect this type of quality here). + Hotate Yaki ($10)- scallops with garlic and asparagus. The scallops were fresh and so buttery. Overall the flavors worked really well together. + Buta Toro ($7)- Pork belly garnished with scallions and red onion. The pork belly arrives sitting in a slightly sweet miso sauce. While it was good, the pork was a tiny bit dry. I wish it had more of a "melt in your mouth" type of texture. (yah know?) + Kalbi Tempura ($10)- Korean style boneless short ribs with vegetables mixed in a sesame ponzu sauce. This is the only dish that I wouldn't order again. It was weird, because the short ribs were fried and really dry. They should have just left the shorts ribs alone. + California Roll ($6)- made with fresh crab meat Yah I know... I'm ordering sushi ROLLS (and I don't even like rolls). But hey, I was craving carbs & they use fresh crab meat here. None of that fake shit. It was bomb. To sum it all up... This place is literally perfect for a fun night out. Social drinking is a big part of the Izakaya experience, so ask your server for some sake recommendations (or beer- whatever floats your bloat!). Since the menu is so extensive, it has a little bit of everything to satisfy anyone's cravings or taste buds. The two "MUST GET'S" are the miso black cod & seafood ramen. PS: Make your ressies in advance. If you come with a large group, get the private rooms! For more pics and deets, visit ze blog: cyneats.com

mE-hdFF4RgCxspZU72GAsw.review_text: On the corner of Geary and Fillmore, I hope this convenient spot does better than the previous incarnation here because this place is really tasty and good. For drinks, the signature Kou is delightfully not too sweet and mixes unique cocktail flavors such as shiso leaf, sochu, umeboshi cherry and soda water. The miso-glazed black cod is a big winner here, as well as the tempura squid with arugula. I was particularly impressed with their red tuna sushi, as it's quality, texture and taste was steps above what you would find in most J-Town joints. Most of all, the staff are super nice and motivated and the ambiance is perfect with seating Japanese booths (please take your shoes off) and normal tables.

EumW_610VLzWwWcDvzr_EQ.review_text: JAMES?! JAMES?! JAMES?!  That was me all night today at Izakaya Kou. James was an amazing host for my boyfriend's 27th! I called on Thursday in hopes that they would have a private room available that would fit our party of 16 - no luck. James did, however, offer me the communal dining area of their restaurant. Basically glass walls surrounding the tables with some gaps here and there for ins and outs. $30 minimum per person, which is super affordable. Not bad considering how last minute I was and my only other choice was Sakesan - where the food is definitely not on par.  I was in my office this morning just spending hours looking through their yelp photos and browsing their menu options to see what to pre-order. It's easier to order ahead when it's a group of indecisive people who will probably take an hour to decide what to order! I called James at 4pm - they weren't even open yet and he answered the phone! I went down the list I had created and he punched in the whole order for me. We came to a $650 total for food and tax which isn't bad at all. They automatically charge 18% gratuity for big parties. He also said he'd have everything set and ready to be cooked so once I arrive there wouldn't be any waiting around for food.  OK, I over-ordered. I thought the guys would be these starving tarzan-like cavemen scarfing down the food before it even touched the table. Boy, was I wrong...we had about 6 boxes of leftovers. Bill came out to be around $800 with gratuity - about $60 a person. SO WORTH IT!  What stood out the most to me was the hamachi carpaccio, the baby octopus! the braised pork belly, the miso cod, and the chicken thigh skewers. Definitely worth trying!  Overall, it was a great dinner and I'm thrilled with the service. I mean, JAMES! Give this guy a raise! or a medal.

Dl5xKwDalYN_BWaus_MetQ.review_text: The food here was very good. It was probably 4-star+ quality food, however I'm docking it a star for service. When I arrived, the restaurant was very empty. The hostess asked if we had a reservation and when we said no she asked if we would mind sitting at the bar. I didn't really understand since the restaurant was empty so I requested a table. She seemed annoyed and took me to a table in a corner of the restaurant, right next to the kitchen. It was not a great place to be seated and impacted my experience at the restaurant. Furthermore, it was hard to get the attention of the waiters - with whom I had no issues - because our table was so out of their eye's view. When I left the restaurant was still half empty.   On the subject of food, I got the California roll (the crab inside was exceptionally delicious), the seaweed salad and the scallops with asparagus in butter sauce (this dish was also absolutely delightful). All these dishes were 5-star quality. The only dish I have any contention with was the salmon sashimi (more like 2.5 stars). It didn't seem as fresh as the other food. I should also mention they have happy hour drinks. I got a draft beer for $3!   Overall, I would recommend this place for the food. The menu is creative and most of what I tried was great. That said, the service could be improved.

heolEa-nF4YtNspCwuYp4g.review_text: This place makes me feel alive!! Friendly staff, good food and nice cold sake!! What else do you need?  Saba tataki - 4/5 Kalbi tempura - 5/5 Hotate katsu - 4/5 Nagasaki Ramen - 5/5

jzxDJ_fNjNeaGoz7QzdB5A.review_text: tl;dr  Really overpriced subpar food. Great ambience, but unless you are literally rolling in dough you can do a lot better in a city like San Francisco.  ----  I very rarely give 2 stars for an establishment. To me, 2 stars means that not only was the food seriously lacking in some aspect, I also feel emotionally cheated by the restaurant (usually by price). Expensive and bad = Izakaya Kou.  Given that over 70% of my reviews are of Japanese places and I jump at the first opportunity to try any new Japanese places (especially those in the $$ and $$$ range), I had high expectations for Izakaya Kou - it had four stars on Yelp, and it was very close to my gf's new apartment on Divisadero - I had high hopes of making Izakaya Kou a regular haunt the way I've enjoyed Izakaya Sozai through the years.  The restaurant itself is quite nice - it's spacious and divided into private rooms and communal dining rooms. At 10 PM on a Friday night, the ambience is more accurately described as calm and subdued, not like the boisterous smoky izakaya ambience that is usually much more common. This is probably a major plus for businessmen looking for a quieter place to talk or for couples seeking a good date spot.   I never give stars based on service, but it was good enough - seating was quick and service was attentive throughout the meal.  Here were the dishes we got:  Buta toro ($7) - the pork belly that so many people have talked about was unfortunately a flop. To be very honest, this dish can be easily made at home. How hard is it to reheat a few pieces of previously-grilled pork belly and squeeze miso sauce+sprinkle some random scallions and onion on top of it? To add insult to the injury, the dish is not even warm when it came out. Come on - you can do better!!  Kabocha croquette ($8) - now this is actually a great dish - 4/5. The kabocha wrapped in fried breading is terrific, and the egg in the middle is delish :) Really tasty and super good value, especially compared to the buta toro that just came out. Very creative dish - a side note is that they probably can hold the sauce/mayo that comes with the croquette - feels like they're a bit too trigger happy with it :)  Sashimi Salad ($13) - this was a joke. Please refer to my picture - you call 3 small mounds of chopped up fish, a cluster of arugula, 5 blueberries (you can count them), and a random dallop of onion a $13 value? Please. Go to any Japanese place and see how a real sashimi salad is done. This is probably the most disappointing of the bunch.  Sake onigiri ($6) - meh. okay. dry rice. very small rice balls. 3/5. not terrible, but not great.  Volcano roll ($14) - since they ran out of their kou ramen, I opted to get a roll instead. It's pretty well done, but as well as any fancy roll in a Japanese place. Is it worth $14? I'm not so sure. Maybe the random slivers of onion they seem to toss on every dish of the restaurant is some organic heirloom onion or something. That was a joke. Ha ha.  When it's all said and done, $61 post-tax and tip. Left hungry. Will certainly not be back.   Honestly, with a drink list as long as the food menu combined with the nice ambience, this place is probably much more suited for businessmen to drink after hours. I would certainly not come back for the food. (but with them charging $17 for a small bottle of Kikusui, I'm not sure whether that's a good reason to come back either...)  In a word, disappointed, and I have no idea what the hype is about. But looks like they're making good money with all these group dinners that appear to be happening in the other reviews.

nprR61-yZvMS1vcgoXBucw.review_text: We found this place on a whim, and I've been so happy with it that I took my dad here for Father's Day.  It's all small plates, so it's best to go with a couple people and share a bunch of plates.  Some of my favorites were the Hamachi Carpaccio, Maguro Tartare, Kabocha Croquette, Tori Kaarage, Lizard Eye (not an actual lizard), and various yakitori.  There's also a good drink selection, which I would expect from an Izakaya.

IyngL8dipT3FB7GNPvV97A.review_text: Good atmosphere. They have low-sitting Japanese tables as an option. Delicious food.

UfTnIzrt4001Q8wtPVutsg.review_text: They have the best Uni onsen and tako yaki. Service was so so as we had a little trouble understanding the wait staff (although she was very nice) but the food is very good here.

WcSUyRH_EzUfqKua1m93DA.review_text: Izakaya Kou bent over backwards for over 80 people at a Yelp event I recently attended. The management and servers exceeded any expectations and truly wanted you to enjoy yourself.   The first thing that impressed me the most was the venue space, it had these great wooden dividers with Japanese style sit down tables.It would be an amazing spot for a birthday party or some sort of group event.   As far as food goes, I'd give it an "A"! The uni and soft boiled egg was so delicate and tasty, great way to start of the meal. All of the sashimi was incredibly fresh, the Japanese bacon pancake was mind blowing and the green tea cheesecake was absolutely delightful!  Let's just say this place doesn't even compare to what it used to be...SO GO SEE IT!

zRKXivafaD2qhKigwGBotg.review_text: New fav izakaya in SF! compared to NY or LA i feel like our izakaya has always been lacking but now we have a new place to hit and the bonus is that besides having great food at reasonable prices....they are open LATE!!  Went here for the first time a few weeks ago and although the service was horrible, the food was stellar all around.  we had.  uni onsen- amazing! assorted nigiri- sushi rice not bad, and fish was very fresh ikura, tamago don- highlight, small but amazing textures, and what can I say we love fish roe! Kurobota pork skewers- very juicy and flavorful.  I think the first time we went they were trying to get their act together and the servers were working with an unfamiliar POS system- we had multiple folks coming to our table asking us about our orders, delivering food that wasnt ours, missing food, repeating ourselves, one other couple even walked out cus they were seated for over 15 minutes with no hello of any sort. They had so many staff there who seemed all confused at that time...it was sort of funny watching them in action   HOWEVER! I went back with a large party last night and the service has gotten much, much better, (we were in tatami area)   in addition to the above, we also got   squid mouth- o so delicious!! kaki fry- fried oysters very good sashimi platter- very good beef tataki- good miso clams very good both types of ramen- i forgot names but both were great okonomiyaki- good takoyaki- just like osaka! spicy tuna roll-good + a bunch of sake!  overall a vast improvement in service although they really should keep to one person and ONE busser serving each table vs random pl coming to and from to help your party.  Its very confusing when other servers deliver your food then you attempt to reorder something but they say they cannot only to leave to try to retrieve the server who is helping you out.....  overall a must hit for izakaya I heart!

KMhKFp6L0bVmsoBFXI_Aog.review_text: Good music playlist, but the bathroom light needs to be brighter. I needed to use my lighter to see where I'm aiming.  oh yea, the food is good as always.

wzpH23Zkd3VJeRAwUzPPQg.review_text: Came with a party of 5, scored a sweet Tatami room, and had 30 min left of happy hour.  The server let us pre-order our drinks so we could get happy hour prices throughout the 2 hours we were there so the drinks could keep flowing on the cheap.    The happy hour deals for both the alcohol and the small plates were incredible.  Very affordable and good portion sizes for $3 and $5 plates.  Our favorites: -Eggplant (my overall favorite) -Fish roe don (rice bowl with variety of fish eggs) -Baby octopus karaage -Chicken karaage -Fresh hamachi sashimi -Okonomiyaki  I'm coming back for sure.

pFd7u3ceGZELQwfnc4VkoQ.review_text: The Yamakake was pretty good, mainly because they used ponzu and the yamaimo didn't numb my mouth too much. The ahi pieces were pretty damn small. I don't know how I feel about the presentation anymore. at first I was surprised at the martini glass presentation, definitely impressive...but its yamakake...dawg wea my rice at??? Had to order rice cause I'm dumb and didn't check when I ordered...but shit too a long time to get to me...and it was just rice in a bowl....and it wasn't busy. Definitely made me unhappy. Second dish was Buta Toro which the white waiter totally butchered he pronounced it Butta Toro and a part of me died inside.   Being an Izakaya I was hoping for some bomb yakitori....but since I'm an ACTUAL purist, I don't eat that tare shit. Asked the waiter if they had shio yakitori and he had nooooo idea what that was. Luckily a Korean broski upped his game and explained they don't do shio on all the items...namely the ones that I actually wanted.   Happy hour is shit. $3 beers the only thing worth while.  Definitely want to bring money, good atmosphere and excellent food quality. Don't get me wrong though, this place definitely smashes the izakaya in the J-center...its just so americany...which is not really a plus.   Also,  CAN OWNERS PLEASE CLEAN THEIR DAMN WINDOWS. so shame already.

yEk2eym9FLT7hKUOZi0Q8Q.review_text: My wife and I went here the other night with a friend for an early dinner before seeing a movie at Kabuki and took advantage of the happy hour deals. The space is pretty neat, wide open and also has some private rooms.   The food was great! We shared maybe 6-8 items and a pitcher of Sapporo. Our waiter, James I think was his name, was great. He was very thorough explaining the menu and giving recommendations on number of items to order and his favorites. The food is definitely Izakaya style. We had several of the skewers, chicken meatballs were my favorite. The fried scallops were also incredible. Food came out pretty quick and was paced well so we weren't overwhelmed by the number of things we ordered.  I hope this place sticks around, will definitely be back!

CXhcRjo0_0VAcJQCSAW7pA.review_text: Love this restaurant - it's our fav sushi spot in the city. Gourmet menu. Reasonable prices. Great ambience and atmosphere. Top notch service.   Highly recommended!

kKLVrIDNmBMXNUjTp5UMog.review_text: Food is very solid but the waitstaff needs a full replacement. I had to ask for everything twice after waiting for our waitress to take care if our table requests that were as simple as getting our first glass of water and ice for the bottle of shochu we got. I want to come back but they'd better up their service mentality for their waitstaff else I'm not coming back.

vXP9TXAvxwzb_iNPJWETXQ.review_text: I'm reviewing for my experience several months ago. The food was mediocre; I've had much much better Japanese food at way better prices. The service was very slow and they completely forgot to bring us one of the dishes we ordered. Didn't even mention it to the waiter because by that time, we didn't even care, we just wanted to leave. We had to go out of our way to get attention from any waiters because all of them seemed to be preoccupied and/or avoiding us. Will not be returning anytime soon.

WPBrjBbk76ZtZQ8QpG09cQ.review_text: Upscale Izakaya (Japanese BBQ skewers) restaurant in Japantown  This place always seems to be packed whenever I stop by, with a line outside. I never realized why until when I actually went in recently--damn, the place is nice!  The decor is very, very well done. We sat at the communal table, next to a "painting" on the wall that looks like it was the side of a tree, with branches, mushrooms, and bark popping out. Combined with the wooden tables, the dishware (stone bowls), and the dim lighting, the place feels very much like a forest, which goes well with the "elemental" vibe of the cuisine.  We ordered the fish roe don (fish roe over rice served in a stone bowl), which was small, but really, really good. The top of the rice was filled with several patches of different kinds of color roes, and the heat made it stick to the rice in a very pleasant way. We also got the chicken thigh skewers, which was ok. The Kalbi Tempura was on the "chef's recommended" list, and was pretty good as well--nice chunks of juicy beef covered by crispy tempura shells, topped with some really well-marinated leaves.  Be sure to book a table or go early, since the place is usually packed!

4sqRqJrIrFYlj8UxbRMJ7A.review_text: I read great reviews about this place and had good expectations, however, my first and only experience was a bit of a let-down.  The interior design is really tasteful - raw wood and beautiful fixtures. They have separate, private rooms for larger parties and seating at the sushi bar.  The wooden table that my guest and I sat at was very small and cramped, I couldn't cross my legs, and we both felt uncomfortable during the entire meal. The first 5 or so wooden tables that seat two people sit in front of the door, so we kept getting chilled.   Our chuhai cocktails were watery and flavorless.  The yellowtail and tuna sushi were fine, nicely sized portions.   The bacon-wrapped asparagus and bacon-wrapped mushroom yakitori were good. However, there was a pretty long wait between our veggie yakitori and our meat yakitori. The chicken was bland (really didn't taste like anything), and the meatballs were dense and just ok.  This was early on a Friday night, and the place wasn't too busy. The wait staff seemed to hover over us, and it feeling cramped and uncomfortable as it was, didn't add to the experience.   The thing that bothered me the most was actually the crappy pop radio they were playing over the speakers. It surprised me considering the place presents itself as upscale (from the website) but it definitely has more of a casual vibe (so be prepared to hear Miley Cyrus during dinner).   We were still hungry by the time we finished but didn't feel like sticking around.

5RPl7M1RpzMvoGx3d-IX7Q.review_text: -Great food, with elegant presentation (not an understatement!) complimented with a huge menu selection made it exciting to look forward to what the next dish to come out would look like -About $25 per person without alcohol. If you do want alcohol there were ginjo and daiginjo 720ml sake bottles in the ~$50 price range, which comes out to about 16 "shots" -very helpful and friendly staff  Will definitely come back again. I've read in a review somewhere that they have a "buy one bottle of sake, get another for $1" deal during HH, but didn't confirm if it was still ongoing

PcEA6B2wN1j0ejKzSlSOzw.review_text: Delicious sushi and yummy ramen. We walked in early evening and were lucky enough to get a seat. We tried the bacon wrapped mushroom, spicy tuna rolls, another avocado/eel roll, and the Nagasaki Ramen. All good, with potent flavors. Loved the seafood/pork/chicken ramen; it had just the right amount of spice. Seems like they have great authentic Japanese dishes.   Service was wonderful and friendly. I'd definitely go back. In my one month officially living in SF, easily the best sushi I've had.

7-9vJ5th5OeTrK59C_GPDg.review_text: I came to Izakaya Kou on a whim because I was seeing a movie at the Kabuki Theatre later that night. I had seen the restaurant in passing a few different times but never had to the opportunity to try it out.  Overall I was relatively satisfied with my meal. We tried an arrangement of different small plates. All small plates + sashimi had really good freshness and flavor. I also appreciated the pace at which the plates came out. Sometimes restaurants don't stagger the dishes well but I thought the service did a good job with that.  The dish with the *best* flavor was the miso marinated black cod (although the portion was much smaller than I expected). The *only* dish I would not recommend is the Hamachi Carpaccio. It was beautiful but bland. A bit anti-climatic.

vTbQZNz8FH4jcrni7Vkl1Q.review_text: Kou has quickly become one of my favoirte izekaya locations in the Japantown area (Sozai still numero uno in sf!).  First - the kabocha croquette - will redefine the whole notion of a croquette.  Second - the interior - is really quite spectacular, and the place deserves a visit just because of the ambiance/decor.  Third Drinks - Izekaya - being a drinking oriented food genre -  specialty cocktails are on the lighter side, and all the obligatory beers and a selection of sake is available. However they did not have Asahi black upon my visit and thats a fail - especially so close to japan town.  Was here for an event and got to try almost the entire menu which was a great experience, everything was delicious and fun was had by all.  If you're considering the venue for an event - I can recommend it as it's laid out in a very interesting way that forces people to congregate in small groups and socialize.

UZloE8c_eUdRoBU47tv2iQ.review_text: Izakaya Kou is the closest I've found to an authentic Izakaya in the Bay Area. Familiar small plates, sushi, pickles and drinks are available. The decor and setting are lovely and the food is good quality.   The service can be a little haphazard, but it feels like they're finding their feet. I have had much better experiences on the weekend than during the week. Be aware that izakaya food is generally shared and so unless you specify you want set dishes per person they will come out 1 or 2 dishes at a time for the table.   A great place for a small to medium group to share some beers and small dishes. Private rooms are available, booking recommended.

5X7FMNE7YZ0WcKxrDz8FEg.review_text: The Nagasaki Ramen was amazing, really spicy with lots of seafood. But the service was disappointing. We waited an entire hour for our food to arrive, each person got his or her meal at a different time, and they completely lost one order of yaki udon. I could understand that (maybe) if it was a busy night, but there were lots of empty tables. An hour? really? For ramen and stir fried udon?  I'll give it another try because the ramen was so good, and hope that it was just a fluke night with the service.

HZ24oVTVz9_2gN1RviAJ1w.review_text: My friends and I came to Izakaya Kou on a whim when we were just chilling in Jtown. We wanted to try something other than the same places we had been frequenting since high school. So I yelped up sushi places, and Izakaya Kou was one of the few highly-rated, reasonably priced sushi joints nearby.  The restaurant itself looks fairly trendy, with wood paneling all over the place, and glass doors separating different sections. There were also sections where you could sit on cushions on the floor, and then closed off by sliding doors. So that was interesting, and I kind of wanted to sit there.  It was kind of loud inside the restaurant, but not overwhelmingly so. I could still hold a conversation with my friends.  Service was a little bit slow, but attentive whenever the servers came by.  Describing this place as sushi would be inaccurate. This place mostly does small plates, although some bigger rice bowls are available. While I would say that this place is a little pricey (forever living on a poor college student budget), the food was fresh and tasty.  I got the chirashi don, which had about 12 pieces of fish (salmon, tuna, shrimp, and a white fish), all of which were quite delicious and had a great texture. It also had 2 pieces of sweet egg, which were equally as good. I enjoyed the whole dish, but I can say that I wasn't completely full from just the chirashi.  Luckily we got other things as well: takoyaki, karage, and kalbi tempura. I thought the takoyaki was well done, crispy on the outside, but not too crispy where you couldn't reach the inside. The kalbi tempura was really tasty and tender, but the serving size was REEEAAALLLY small. The karage was average. My friend also got a unagi don, and that piece of eel was HUMONGOUS. And delicious.  We were here during happy hour too, so we got a couple of Sapporos for $3 each. Which is a good price for those I think. And the appetizers (takoyaki, karage) were $5 each. So happy hour is not too shabby :)  Overall, I would definitely come here again, but probably during happy hour.

RPtDPYhO1VckFZsjQ-Vv3A.review_text: We got a private room for about 7 or 8 of us and it was a blast. Great food and great sake. Most of the tapas like items were very good. Specifically the baby octupus, seaweed salad, and eggplant dish.

ZIc-wHerFTKzLvnylyOoFw.review_text: We came here for the Happy Hour but also ordered entrees as well. Everything was really good. The Happy Hour menu is limited but still a great sampling to have some lights bites and cheap Sapporo pints ($3). I also got the frisco roll which was delicious and my guy who doesn't really eat seafood got some beef and pork dishes (those were a little on the small side so if you have a big appetite maybe stick to the sushi rolls).

mDQnPtVsjxKQh8Oo2fjjTA.review_text: Excellent food and service. Great spot to try before a show at The Fillmore. I will be back!

1KhECADi-6mS26dc5jsrtw.review_text: Good fresh food. A bit pricey but that is to be expected of an Izakaya. Would probably come back again if I'm in the area.

QIssYBaARBy_7lv6hT-ATA.review_text: Amazing food, service not good unless you are a Japanese national! Sanseis like me will be ignored!

8qpFUPR1wd3uz8N1QaWj_A.review_text: Was here recently for a Yelp event.  Having patronized the prior establishment, it was nice to see this floor space totally transformed with an enclosed dining room by the entrance, several Tatami rooms on the left, communal tables and regular tables in the middle and bar seating next to the sushi station and kitchen.  Though we were here for a special event, the food that we tried were items directly from the restaurant's regular menu. Our Starters and menu selections: Uni Onsen Tamago: soft boiled cage-free w/uni in KOU sauce. This was a unique dish and the uni was nicely complemented by the soft boiled egg. (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Dengaku Miso:  grilled eggplant w/miso sauce.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Kalbi Tempura:  fried Korean style boneless short rib and vegetables mixed with sesame ponzu.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…) Gindara Misozuke: miso marinated black cod. Delicious. Reminded me of butterfish.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Buta Kakumi: Japanese braised pork belly. What can I say?  It's pork belly!  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Hamachi Kama:  yellowtail collar. This was good, but felt the collar was on the smaller side.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Chirashi Don:  assorted sashimi over sushi rice.  Nice slices of Hamachi, salmon, tuna, albacore and two ebis.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Okonomiyaki: Japanese style pancake with bacon.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Kou Sashimi:  salmon, Hawaiian big eye tuna, and yellowtail.   (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Ankimo: steamed monkfish liver with ponzu.  As close as you can get to the "non-p.c." foie gras?  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…). Nagasaki Ramen: vegetables & seafood in white spicy pork & chicken broth. Tasty broth...  must be the pork.  (yelp.com/biz_photos/elit…) Overall, the service was friendly and efficient.  The food was very good and we're happy we were able to try so many of the restaurant's menu offerings.  If in the area, will definitely come back to Izakaya Kou.

zi5LgjU_8FGkRCwDni8v6w.review_text: I came here last night for my roommate's birthday dinner and it was a pretty good experience! We made reservations for 5:30pm but we ended up being really late. We let them know that we were running late and they were very accommodating. Because we were in a bigger group, we were seated in the private tatami room. I thought this was awesome and absolutely perfect for the occasion. I also loved the decor throughout the restaurant. It's all beautiful~  We made it in time for happy hour so we were able to get the deal where you buy one sake and get the second one for $1. By the way, know that the hot sakes here aren't hot. No, they are not even lukewarm. They are cold.. I'm not quite sure why they are called hot sakes. As for food, I tried the Yaki Udon and the Frisco roll. Both were delicious and the presentation was amazing. I liked that the udon had a lot of seafood and vegetables in it and the roll was fresh and flavorful.  The only issue we had was with the service. To put it simply, it was not good. Our waitress would only check up on us when we pressed the button to call her and she was really bad at answering our questions. Maybe she was new..? I'm not sure but the service could definitely use some work.

65VHiQMlmGIDEFMa0akoUg.review_text: Horrible customer service. I would have given it no star if there was the option. We were sitting at the table where the sun directly hits us. We asked one of the waitresses if we can move to another table or if they can do something about that. She said the other tables were reserved and wouldn't let us move or do anything about it. We were all wearing sunglasses inside the restaurant as we ate which was not enjoyable. After over an hour later, the tables which she said they were "RESERVED" were still empty. The restaurant was very empty the entire time. It totally made sense because of their horrible customer service.... We would not be one of the repeat customers and would not recommend our friends to go there. Also, they charged us $2 each for the tea which were usually free at other restaurants. What a rip off!

f7pbQuon-3GbyNbzcNSQdQ.review_text: pros...this is one of cool japanese taverns, which is a great place to have some alcohol and also some good eats as well.  izakaya kou is a great place just to hang out and have some fun as well. best part is that they have the semi private rooms with the cut out for your feet.  a great little table that seats about 5-6 comfortably and 7-8 in a more friendly manner.  as for the food, it was great.  you have such a wide selection of food types: sushi, sashimi, ramen, yakitori, soups, salads, rice, fried foods all is good here.  we happen to have just about a little bit of everything that night.  best part of the night was exploring the menu and finding yet another delicious thing to eat.  but besides food, there was also a great deal on the beer and also the sochu or soju.    as for service, that was great.  we had one main server who was super cool, she was attentive without being intrusive.  things were refilled well and the food came out at a nice pace.  not hurried, but very comfortable pace to eat and talk and eat again.  and once again all in the privacy of your own room.    cons...well of course we are in the city, so things can get a bit expensive, but the answer to that is to come during happy hour, where some of the stuff is going to be less expensive.  other con, i wish we had one of these of this calibre in San Diego.  otherwise it was really a great night, pre birthday party for me.

WTMS8FIAe_qhYLfTiPvD0A.review_text: This Japanese restaurant is my favorite!! They always have great service as well as awesome food! Their TATAMI room is great and love to have some privacy. Very reasonable price and recommend to everyone! Lastly great atmosphere always makes me don't want to leave. Try out you will never regret it!

sBReCygAeC4Jhyihl7uUXQ.review_text: Who says you can't just walk into a restaurant in SF @ 8pm and not get seated?!? Well, the stars aligned this last weekend and that's just what we did here at Izakaya Kou. Granted we were seated in a tiny two-top by the kitchen, but we didn't care due to the amazing luck.   The food was very good, also considering the price. The spicy tuna salad was super spicy. Great for me, but too much for my wife, so keep that in mind for people sensitive to it.   Had some sushi, it was good. Not amazing, but not bad by means. $5 for nigiri was pretty middle of the road.   My favorite was the tonkatsu scallops. Crunchy on the outside and light and delicious on the inside. They came out piping hot from the kitchen and were accompanied by a great dipping sauce. If you're a scallop fan, get these. Really good value for the $8.   Interesting beer and sake list. Didn't try any of the sake due to the fact that we had just visited from Sake Day over at the Japanese Cultural Center nearby.

_1_eRkJDiAx0KMkRJncA9g.review_text: Very tasty sushi, nice people and a spacious environment. The wait has never been long for me, and it's quiet enough that you can hear each other without having to raise your voice. The location is easy to find and it's very close to the Kabuki theater if you want to catch a bite before the movie.

xIwXStH_2AQb6vVzkexroA.review_text: Great izakaya place! 5 of us sat in their small tatami rooms that has a $200 minimum, which was not hard to hit. The room so had a bell on the wall for calling the servers' attention, which is very common in japan. We ordered about 15 different dishes (some doubled), 3 bottles of sake, 2 pitchers of beer and another bottle of beer. It totaled to about $300, which seems reasonable to me. For those of you unfamiliar, izakaya is like a tavern that specialized in grilled tapas. This place also had raw food, lots of fried options, ramen, donburi and other typical japanese snack foods served at beer houses like Tako yaki and kaki fry.  The food was in general above average and the decor and atmosphere was very Californian. It's a very fun and welcoming place to hang out with friends for drinking, chatting and eating without having to scream and loosing your voice!

Ace-HUw-c1f9zJr4QfJjQQ.review_text: The hubby was initially skeptical of visiting a restaurant that hasn't even been open for an entire week but we decided to try it out anyway thanks to its proximity to the Japanese market.  I'm definitely glad we decided to risk it because we had a great experience!  They were extremely accommodating of our 8 month old son, gave us a fairly secluded corner table (it helped that we went early and were the first ones there) and best of all they commented how cute he was but no one tried to touch him (total pet peeve when waiters touch his face since he is a preemie)!     Food highlights for me were definitely the Hotate (scallop) Gratin and the sake nigiri.  I would go back for these two things alone.  I'm not exaggerating when I say the sake nigiri was some of the best I've ever had.  Generous slices of fish that just melted in your mouth - yum.  And the scallops were so freaking delicious that I literally licked the shells.  Yes, it was that good.  My only gripe is that there were only three per order!  That was my own fault though, I really should have gotten two orders.  The hubby's favorite was the clam miso soup, TONS of clams and the broth was light and flavorful at the same time.    I can't say enough about how great the service was.  The waiter thought we had ordered sashimi instead of nigiri and due to the mixup they gave us an extra order of each nigiri for free!  They didn't have to do that, especially since the food came out so quickly so we really didn't have to wait long for the correct order to come out AND they gave us the 10% first week discount too.  Dishes were cleared quickly and the servers were always asking to check how everything was and if we needed anything else.    I'm officially a big fan of this place and hope they do well so I can come back for the scallops for years and years to come!  (But not so well that I won't be able to get a table if I go at 5:30 lol).

FJWk6Qr_ZLVPgcLS0xPlvQ.review_text: Been here 3 times already since they've opened. Delicious food, great atmosphere, and friendly staff. They have a wide selection of food and sake on the menu. I'm excited for my next visit! It can be a little pricey but well worth the price. Definitely a place worth checking out!

ftpfgb4IvNfwroUxuYTl-g.review_text: I went there with my friends yesterday!!! I like this restaurants' atmosphere, which was cozy and oriental style. I hope ur guys go there and taste this fantastic cusine. They have various food, and it was better than I expected.I and MY friends had a great time there.I think this restaurant is the place that I am looking for in SF. The flavos of Izaka food are sure to excite your taste buds!!!!!

neNSB3Sly1wUS6HFHLMang.review_text: I had heard great things about this place and heard from Japanese circles that the place is run by Japanese. I guess I had higher expectations, but I felt they might be trying to do too much. They are an izakaya, afterall, but seems to serve at least one of every type of Japanese dish including ramen (seems de riguer in the US, but you will not typically find ramen at izakaya in Japan), sushi (sashimi or raw fish yes, but not sushi), kushi yaki, koroke, wow, just every thing was on that menu! We tried sashimi (fish seemed like it was frozen then thawed), sansai ika (a bit dry), yakitori (too sweet!). Sunomono was good. Gyoza seemed a bit sweet and mushy. Nice selection of sake, but the brands are relatively easy to find elsewhere in J Town. Draft beer is Sapporo. Service was fine. Efficient and courteous. Interiors seemed to follow the usual SF trend of exposed wood. Nice to have private 'tatami' areas. Maybe this place is good for non-Japanese who could use a basic introduction to 'real' Japanese food, but if you know good Japanese food, then you might be a tad disappointed.

p_4jHMF9f96hXs09ekilKQ.review_text: so much fun to try all the small plates - I only wish we'd had a bigger group so we could have sampled more! But as it was we ate: hamachi carpaccio: fresh, clean kabocha croquette creamy, fried, salty yum chicken tsukune: umami, grilled, savory caterpillar: luscious, crunch, bbq hotate yaki: maybe the only eh in the bunch kaki fry: crispy, salty, sea  the sake flight was to die for - perfect sized sips (1.5 oz) of sakes that are normally only available by the bottle.

eH034FAZ5xfMFl21yKnhcA.review_text: After months of anticipation for their advertised "Coming March 2013", I'd given up hope that I'd ever be able to try their food.  But, after seeing signs of life in July and August, hope picked up again.  You can see the amount of work that had been put into this place since Nan closed, and I think it looks great inside.  They have the Japanese-style seating on one side (with at least one table kind of a cool hybrid), and regular tables in the middle.  And the menu has a number of dishes that look really good and a nice sake selection.  So, I was really looking forward to tasting the food.  But, the actual execution fell short.  It all *looks* good.  Like, with the fancy flourishes with the sauce - you know - when they add the sauce on parts of the plate, but not actually on the food.  But, here's the thing: unless the sauce is just garnish, that fancy flourish just makes it harder to eat.  Some dishes were approached "alright" (with the tofu temptation making it into the "good" category), but mostly, it felt like they came up with the dish, then moved on to the next without  taking the time to perfect it.  And, since they cover just about every section of Japanese cuisine, seems almost inevitable.  The ramen was the huge disappointment.  The Kou ramen was reminiscent of Tampopo's Kyushu ramen, which you could have gotten away with everyone and their brother opened a ramen shop in SF.  But, if you want to be taken seriously, you should really take the time to do it right, and, if it's not working, don't put it on the menu.  (Or, maybe have it on the specials board to experiment.)  Note for the servers: When you are bringing a plate of "oyster mushrooms", if you leave out one of those two words, leave out "oysters", not "mushrooms".  My advice would be to cut the menu in half, and try and focus on a few dishes that they know they can do well.

vUI0jXAxFDzoLX04jN9RPA.review_text: It's rare for me to say this but damn, this place is good! I would definitely bring someone here. It's super hipster and cool inside, with wooden decor and tables. I love the modern and airy feel.  The dishes are Japanese but with a twist. They will have dishes you won't see anywhere else. The quality and quantity as well as pricing was all decent especially for being in that neighborhood.  1. Egg pumpkin puff- delicious!!! The egg was runny, the pumpkin was sweet and the sauce and crunchy outside was perfection.  2. The uni something in the glass- omg. Good. I can just drink it.  3. The Frisco roll- yum!   4. The seafood ramen- spicy and yummy!  5. Chicken karage- yum! Crispy! With Siracha mayo.  6. Pork belly- this was ok.  All in all, a wonderful experience and food came out at a good pace. The workers were friendly.  Iza my type of place!

jMgetwOspGQQFhJs4fDwuA.review_text: I had really fantastic dinner at this place! Susi were fresh and good, and Kabocha Croquette was the BEST for me. It tasted so new and awesome! The service was good as well so I'm giving five stars :)

FG_ZKIMm-jMilGfACcgCSg.review_text: I like the food, the service could be a bit better, usually end up waiting around for someone when it gets a bit busier. Super close to the fillmore for easy dinner/drinks before a concert.

f_oFXzuujrl-ZG6tR7O81w.review_text: Food tasted as if the staff had left it out on the counter for a day or so, almost moldy, that said the service was not up to par I think Taco Bell is much better! It is a cute little place but the management needs to clean up their act a bit....

P5bUL3Engv-2z6kKohB6qQ.review_text: I never ate at the Korean joint that existed before this, but I did hit the Thai place before that. Let me tell you this place has been really transformed. Looking for a quick meal before a Fillmore show, we were denied by Prime Dip and State Bird. So we walked in here seeing a group of 12 before us. Shoot. But the hostess recognized we were stuck in back and we got a table immediately. Lifesaver. We were back near the bar between the tatami rooms and counter service, giving a good view of most of the restaurant Lots of wood, dimly lite. Very well appointed in a more modern way. Got:  -kaboCha Croquette boiled cage-free egg inside of pumpkin puffs   -Chicken Tsukune  chicken meatball  -kurobuta  black pork  -hamachi kama yellowtail collar  -hawaiian poke salad  hawaiian big eye tuna mixed w/sea veggies and seasonal vegetables in spicy sauce  -okonomiyaki japanese style pancake with bacon  Everything was fairly tasty. Portions are actually bigger than I thought they'd be. Staff are attentive and the food came out fast. We were out in under an hour. Definitely a place of consideration if you're trying to hit a show across the street with little time. Just make sure you dont get stuck behind 12 people!

y0rtNjNGdfULY_p-kTs4Nw.review_text: My boyfriend and I love this place. Great food, excellent service.   We've been here several times now, brought friends a few times, and even tried one of the group rooms. Every visit was wonderful.   I personally loved the Kabocha Croquette (it's HUGE compared to the other appetizers btw), the Tofu Temptation (not shareable, only 3 spoons). The Buta Toro was also fantastic and their sushi is delicious. I was pleasantly surprised by the size of their fish cuts as well (despite their normally tiny portions).   My only wish is that they had a seasonal fish menu and that they had Sweet Shrimp! =)

irgRhiwd69JNVsNwFiL1BA.review_text: This place is a big no for me. Unpleasant enough to leave after being sat down, or actually, being to forgotten about at the bar. The hostess (blonde, 5'4ish, glasses) was one of the biggest reasons we left because she set a bad vibe. We hung back so we didn't bombard her (it wasn't busy at all, a handful of tables - I know what it's like having been a hostess/waiter before to get stressed out by waiting customers), waiting for her to call us but was rude with an grouchy/mean expression on her face. We sat at the bar for awhile without being acknowledged so we thought it was just best to leave. Another thing that added on to the unpleasant experience was the language they were using. I speak Korean & the chefs at the bar were using curse words & whatnot.

N_yNJpSDHVVGP7jsshIyKA.review_text: We got the caterpillar roll, O-something sake, porcupine cabernet sauvignon, and the king oyster mushrooms. I had the caterpillar mostly so I can only talk about how fresh that was and I really enjoyed it. I heard the mushroom with the mango spicy sauce was pretty good. Kind of on the expensive side but I liked the very raw decor of the place...and located right around the corner from the Sundance Kabuki Theater. And it's open until 11pm I believe.

urqtKpxG3VM6C2vxhb1ilA.review_text: I went to Izakaya Kou last night for a Yelp Elite event (so my review may differ slightly from a non-special event meal). I must say, Izakaya Kou really played to their strengths. Normally, I don't crave izakaya. Between the various styles and dishes of Japanese cuisine, I lean towards ramen joints. However, this was a fabulous experience and meal!  Among the food sampled was the Uni Onsen Tamago. It is basically uni with a soft-boiled cage-free egg and their special Kou sauce sitting pretty in a martini glass. Very delicate flavors. I loved the thinly sliced red onions on top. Though I'm not crazy about uni, it was nevertheless refreshing. The dengaku miso was one of my favorites of the evening. It is grilled eggplant with a miso sauce. The kalbi tempura was also excellent and I wish I could've had more!   With fellow Yelpers, we shared: Okonomi Yaki ($12), Kou Ramen ($11), Kuo Sashimi ($18), Hamachi Kama ($12), Yaki Udon ($11), Salmon Skin Katsu ($7), Nagasaki Ramen ($14), and 2 green tea cheesecakes ($7 each). Among that list, it was agreed that the grilled hamachi was a "must try." The okonomi yaki was also on point. I mean, how could you lose with a pancake loaded with bacon?!! The salmon skin katsu was a crowd-pleaser. The salmon was fried to perfection -- didn't turn out dry from the battered outer layer. The Nagasaki ramen was the better between the two ramens we ordered. The broth was delicious and the slight spiciness thanks to the jalapeño provided a nice kick! Now... dessert should always complete a meal and the green tea cheese cake really did! Subtle and rich at the same time -- is that possible?! It was accompanied with -- brace yourself... LAVENDER HONEY ICE CREAM FROM BI-RITE CREAMERY (my favorite flavor from Bi-Rite!). I thought it was vanilla upon seeing it, and once I put it in my mouth (keep it G-rated folks), I pretty much made the loudest "food-gasm" sound. The green tea cheesecake and the ice cream in one bite was euphoric.   In terms of cocktails, we tried the Samurai, Ginger Cooler, Love Hotel, and the Kou. I loved the Ginger Cooler most because it was refreshing and the combination of ginger, ginger-ale, sake, and lime was an apt beverage for the meal. A close runner-up was the Samurai.   The service was fantastic. Though it was for a private event and there were multiple servers taking care of the whole restaurant, our server Diane was so sweet, attentive, and very thorough in her descriptions of the dishes. I believe she said she mainly works Tuesdays and Wednesdays  (?), so if you get her, you'll be in good hands.   The interior... the only way I can describe it is... rustic Japanese meets modern American -- if that makes sense. There are Tatani rooms where shoes must be off in traditional Japanese settings, and there are communal dining tables as well. There is a lot of wood action happening at Izakaya Kou. The lighting is a soft yellow dim and its corner location allows for reasonable people-watching views.  Overall, I plan to return. I remember seeing this being constructed every time I'd walk along Fillmore and last night was a fantastic reason to try this spot. I would return in a minute with friends and loved ones. The food and the setting allow for a convivial feel. Also... if you want a cute date spot with sexy sharing food and a fun vibe, this is your place San Francisco. Bow-chicka-wow-wow. I highly recommend this spot. It'll exceed your expectations!

SrR2QuFU04EuYgsoKKh8Ww.review_text: Solid place and great service. We sat in one of those private rooms, which was a fun experience.  We ordered a TON of food and the bill was still very reasonable at the end of the night.  Also a great selection of sake that isn't too overwhelming nor limited.

_XvuuSBHNvXC4eziLEpbkA.review_text: Wow. Do not ask for ramen at this place...  I came here because it was in walking distance from my house and I was craving ramen.   My boyfriend and I were seated right away, and we each ordered ramen.  He decided on the seafood ramen, and I opted for the traditional.  A few minutes later the waitress came back to tell us they were out of the seafood ramen.. so my bf ordered the regular as well.  I  am no ramen expert which is why I went to a restaurant to get it but I know it does not take 45 minutes to make!  (we were there on  a weeknight where the place was not crowded by any means but there were other people in the restaurant) We waited and waited with empty drinks and an empty table and finally the two bowls of ramen were brought out.   The ramen:  two bowls of the exact same order.. at first glance, my bf had about a third less amount of broth as me, so instead of listening to him complain to the waitress I poured some broth from my bowl to his.  Then we started eating it and the vegetables in it (which were too many for my taste) were overcooked, while the noodles seemed undercooked. BLAHHHH!  He was a little dramatic and stopped eating it altogether, but I was hungry so I ate just the noodles in my bowl.   The manager apologized and offered us a free beer, which I didn't take but my bf did since he had nothing else.   There are so many better places to get ramen or anything else Japanese that I won't be back here.

NO5e0WtLAOYcjheLU6OEVg.review_text: Came here for a late dinner.  The ambience is modern, spacious, and very clean.  It wasn't busy so we were seated right away.  Tables and chairs are made of wood.  They also have private Tatami rooms which is good for a party of five to eight.   ::Drinks:: I got the Chuhai which is a Japanese cocktail.  It's blood orange juice with Japanese vodka. I don't think I got blood orange juice, instead it tasted like regular orange soda.   (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) ::Food:: The Bacon Enoki is basically wrapped in bacon.  I thought it was bland and I couldn't taste the bacon.  Then we got the Kurobuta Sausage which is Black Pork Sausage, it was "ok".  I like Manila clams so we got the Asari Miso.  It was served in a small bowl filled with Manila clams, miso broth, and topped with parsley; it was salty.  I saw a lot of pictures of the Kalbi Tempura so I decided to try it.  It's Korean Style boneless short ribs with vegetables and mixed with sesame ponzu sauce.  The short rib was chewy and the tempura was soggy; I didn't like it.   (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) ::"Meh" Moment:: We were looking forward to eating the Nagasaki Ramen but unfortunately we didn't get to because they took a long time to make it. We finished all our food and it still wasn't ready.   ::Rating:: The ambience is nice but I wasn't satisfied with the food. ::M's Notes:: ~Inside seating ~Reservations available online.

IO4ZbLWjUM18uC1TS3U2PQ.review_text: This is a real find! Excellent food (try the eggplant dish or the blackened cod or very spicy Hawaiian Poke, which were superb), speedy and wonderfully helpful service, and a large selection of fine saki and wine at a reasonable price. It's new, and we plan to return very soon to try other items from the soups and fried list -- the menu is extensive!

jpl1W8uMWbil8ixuI1QbbA.review_text: We stumbled upon this restaurant when we couldn't get into another place nearby.  We are glad we did!  The décor was awesome!! Lots of wood and these cool, private areas for larger groups.   The food was good, we shared a sushi roll and both had the ramen. The broth and goodies in it were delicious.  Service was great, would definitely love to return with a group and sit in the secret cubbies!

h4CI0N2UB8KL7zK-JaHe7w.review_text: I had a party inside of their tatami room last weekend and it was amazing. The staff was friendly and food was delicious, especially the nagasaki ramen and tako wasabi.

pJ9bcaml-WCxl74p-i7FlA.review_text: If the restaurant advertises it closes at 10pm on a Sunday and you wanna grab a quick sushi roll to go at 9:31pm - don't bother, the kitchen closes at 9:30pm

-4uJ9HeVqFhfX28OaxvNBg.review_text: damn best japanese in town and you won't regret it

FHbWz5kgIXBcDHdNfCLhNg.review_text: Place is legit!  Forget the carpaccio stuff and fusion whatevers, the sushi/fish is fresh and no frills.

Juh-g9sATZppHvMmNmHfFw.review_text: This location is at a walkable distance to Japantown (around 5-10 mins?) so you don't need to worry about parking. In my experience, Izakaya is usually in a small compact environment, with traditional Japanese feeling. Not anything like that here, it's classy, it has high ceilings, very spacious, and it plays light classical music. Anyway, the dishes:  - Maguro Tartare: big eye tuna chopped sashimi (it seems this restaurant emphasizes "big eye" a lot as all tuna dishes on menu are big eye tuna) with raw egg. Mix it together and eat; interesting texture, and good as a first dish - Dengaku Miso (eggplant): a must to order whenever I go izakaya not only because I like eggplant, but apparently all Izakaya I have been to had some very different cooking method of this dish. In here, it got a quarter size of a Japanese fat eggplant, so big that you would think the middle of the eggplant will be not as good but NOT - the miso taste was strong, not too hard/soft, and the skin was soft as well - Hotate Yaki: another amazing dish but not because of the scallop, but because of the asparagus - it totally felt like a Chinese stir-fry asparagus scallop dish in local low cost hawkers store; but really, this dish was just phenomenal! - Buta Toro: this one is alright; wouldn't order it next time though - Kalbi Tempura: a dish that I would have never ordered but my friend did - and it turned out to be as amazing as the Hotate Yaki. I always thought Kalbi was only for Korean BBQ but I would have never imagined it can be made as tempura with wonderful taste!! Must try! - Frisco Roll - a regular sushi roll but the fish was fresh and I could instantly tell the chef paid a lot of effort to make it good - Momo skewers: chicken thigh yakitori, a bit overcooked, kind of hard - Mushroom Enoki skewers: not too bad, enoki mushroom smelled good - Ika Yaki (whole grilled squid): descent, nothing too special - Kabocha Croquette: we added this as additional order but we waited for a long time and it didn't came; asked the waiter and found that the chef overcooked the original one and had already started cooking a new one for us instead. I give one additional star just because of the persistence the chef has about his food  Other than that, the waitress service was a bit disappointing, very very small voice, could barely hear what she said; although I could tell she was doing her best and she had a nice attitude at least.  Definitely a coming back to this restaurant! Next time with a larger group though, those private rooms look really nice and cozy. One of my new favorite SF Izakayas!

AuXucaYN2ts9XNk-plKTeQ.review_text: I go to Japantown often, but I have never been this place before. This place is fabulous. Great ambiance and friendly service. We ordered Tako Wasa, Ika Sansai, Kabocha Croquette, Poke, Yakitori Momo and Tsukune, Karaage, Takoyaki, and Yaki Onigiri. Everything was good, and I really enjoyed Poke and Kabocha Croquette. It was in Happy Hour, so beer was only $3. I will definitely come back to Kou!

aYgkKslXRA8u0WbvRtpjSw.review_text: I was recently visiting from LA and heard about this new place on Fillmore and Geary. I was so excited having passed by earlier in the day... and then so disappointed after leaving. I'm really not sure where the other people who reviewed this restaurant ate. Definitely not here.  I'll make the review short and sweet. For ambiance, this place gets an A+. It's great -- nice lighting, nice space, not too loud, and pretty comfortable. For service, this place gets an A. Our server was nice, funny, and very helpful. For food, this place gets nothing better than a C- or C. We had a speciality roll, which was probably a B-, squid, which was a C, and short ribs that were rubbery and, basically, the nasty shit you've ever tasted. So, F. I think that would all be okay if everything was priced lower, but this is not a cheap place to eat. It's not particularly expensive either, but for the food quality, it was definitely over priced. I love supporting new businesses, and although the place looks awesome and the staff is great, the food sucked.  Fix the most important part of the experience and I'll be back.

GDAwnhCzH0s7x6YrBigOAQ.review_text: I went here with a group on a Saturday night for dinner. The concept is great if you can reserve a private Tatami room. You just have to press a button on the wall when you want to order something. Very cool. I tried this sparkling "jelly" cocktail that was unlike any drink I ever had. The consistency really was jelly-like. I'd recommend trying it if you like sweet drinks. Although I really liked the ambiance, I didn't care much for the food. I enjoyed the hamachi carpaccio, however the beef tataki, gyoza, icy soba and kabocha croquette were underwhelming. The layer of pumpkin on the croquette was way too thick. The whole Japanese fusion didn't work for me. I'd almost like to see them stick with more traditional preparation done really well.

KRfRO8yMi4pCb9Sh8-vGzg.review_text: Meh. It's ok. Nothing special. The service is excellent. The food is nothing to write home about. But not bad either.

gVddqshP7KTJvzycrw1_5Q.review_text: The food's nice so we used to get take-out from here. But I don't think we will anymore because I found out that they increased the tip amount on our credit card without our approval. Hate restaurants that do that. Is that even legal?

ItTeqxJWiW_1IzQ1wTAL9g.review_text: Aesthetics: Earthy wood walls, floors, tables, and chairs, all monochromatic and minimalist without feeling oppressive or sterile.  Twisting tree trunks jutting out of the floor.  Air plants and branches growing out of the walls.  Enclosed rooms with sliding wood doors with floor pillow seating.  Edison bulbs, of course.  I want to redo my apartment exactly like this now.  I couldn't stop thinking about the interior design.  It's genius.    Food: The presentation was pure art.  We ordered Kou Sashimi, Croquette, Volcano Roll, and Shishito Peppers.  The Kou Sashimi melts in your mouth.  Will definitely order again.  Then I cut open the croquette and to my surprise, an egg had been concealed inside, yolk sensually oozing onto the plate.  I like the feeling of the egg gently popping open, the layers and textures...  Like a haiku, the croquette seems simple on the surface, yet contains so much within...  Service: Food arrived FAST!  Staff is friendly, easy-going, and polite, and I was happy to be spared the usual inauthentic small talk bullshit.  They simply did their jobs well so I could comfortably focus on eating without having to socially exert myself.  I'm an introvert in a noisy overpopulated city, so I treasure any moment I can space-out freely with minimal intrusion.  Food orgasms are best experienced sans interruption mid-chew.  Ambience: Despite being full of people, this is an oasis of calm, which is a rare thing to find in San Francisco.  I can't remember the last time I wasn't bumping elbows with the table next to me, or not being forced to eavesdrop on loud strangers seated too close.  Introvert approved!  Verdict: A novel dining experience.  Stylish spot for friend gatherings, yet sophisticated enough to bring parents, co-workers, or a discerning date.  We waited 30 minutes on a sunday night but it gave us time to decide what to order, and the atmosphere is so lovely I really didn't mind hanging out for a bit in their waiting chairs.  Get a reservation if you don't want to wait.

xGDcXcscWQl_X0R3f1LIzw.review_text: Overall very satisfied with my meal. Good sushi and non-sushi items on the menu. We grabbed a couple items here and there and made a meal out of small dishes. Service was great, the location is great being right on Geary, and the price is comparable with other 4 star japanese joints. Izakaya has a business casual vibe meaning you should dress up a little, and expect a lot of hard wood and dim lighting. Oh and when you've ordered all of your lovely sushi/sashimi/rolls, make sure to get an order of the pork belly with kimchi - so delicious!

hETgHml_EJ17ry4r_N8A-w.review_text: My friend and I were looking for ramen during the J Pop festival and found Izakaya Kou. They weren't open yet when we called but the staff was very helpful and advised us to show up a little early so we could get a table right when they opened at 5:30.  We were lucky enough to get seated and were able to order fairly quickly. I had the seafood ramen, which I'm no expert on, but it was delicious and the portion size was reasonable (not too big). My friend had an undon stir fry dish and really enjoyed that as well. Both dishes were flavorful and contained a nice variety of seafood.  This was an extremely busy day, but the wait staff was as attentive as could be expected, our water glasses were always full and they even split our check for us. We also really enjoyed the ambiance of the restaurant. It felt tastefully minimalist and modern but the strategic placement of glass walls and partitions meant that it was not too loud or full of echoes.

HCtEYgABFgwGhHB3rPQeQQ.review_text: Service could not be any slower.  It literally took almost 20 minutes before someone even came over to acknowledge our existence.  I will say food is great, space is beautiful,  but based on the service, I'm not sure I will be back  Mushroom wrapped bacon....amazing tho!

_eRTv9-B33t0ybQaYz-C1Q.review_text: It is very oily and they put a lot of salt in ramen . The food is not very good but service are fine .

Vab-TCp-yAz_UmT0ereFRQ.review_text: Love Love Lovin' this place!!!  Excellent fresh food!  Sushi and pork belly was perfection! Excellent customer service! James the host was super nice and welcoming.  He even brought us complimentary strawberry ice cream for dessert...talk about stepping out of the box. Will D-E-F-I-N-I-T-E-L-Y be coming back!

vqBuGCz3DNNXLU03rpu0LA.review_text: If you're feeling fiesty, get the uni w onsen tamago. Lovely presentation. I dare you to eat it shooter style!

8p4w0obQ4tBStWw13omWig.review_text: We went and sat at the sushi bar. The sushi was fresh and good. I liked this place but there wasn't a lot about it that made is super special. There is a lot great places around and this place is one of them. If I was in the area I would definitely hit this place up again but I am not sure I'd self motivate to go again.

R1xTLNoaSGgMg96PGpRzOQ.review_text: Ramen noodles way too soft, toppings burnt. Okonomiyaki undercooked inside. Buta k akuni good. Good service.

2XLyYL5c9eUpGGz6JZLvMw.review_text: Don't let the outside look fool you! It's beautiful on the inside. I only took one star off for poor service and the fact that they didn't have that much selection when it comes to food, especially the sushi rolls selections was what annoyed me most. I was out of water for like 10 minutes and my friends teeny scallops came before my sushi. Not sure how that happened but okay. The miso soup was pretty delicious as was my sushi roll (volcano roll), it didn't fill me up but it did take away my hunger. Overall I would come here again, maybe with a group the try that "private" style Japanese tea house rooms they have.

qNrHLZPurBWJzeAMkFLvvA.review_text: Highlights - I've seen their coming soon sign and they were originally suppose to open earlier this year, but it is finally here months later and I have to say that it is beautifully decorated with minimalist nature feel. Walking in makes you feel like you are transformed into a different environment with the wooden tables, decor, and private rooms.  - The perfect place to have a intimate event by reserving one of their private rooms or just a casual dinner at the bar or one of their tables within the restaurant.  - Food is delicious during my first visit and thanks to a recent YEE that I attended again here, I had the opportunity to even try more of their fantastic dishes.  - Items that stood out: Kabocha Croquette (Deep fried pumpkin ball wrapped egg), Uni Onsen Tamago (soft poached egg with uni served in a martini glass), KuruMa rbi Zuke (raw prawn in soy sauce marinade w/ onigiri) - Best drink: The Samuri (Sake, Cucumber, Lemon, and Apple juice). Refreshing and thirst quenching.  - Service was attentive and the best I have had. I had the same server both times and she was on her A-game. Ready to swap out chopsticks that dropped, clear out any trash on the table, provide you with extra napkins, and on it when you need something.   Improvements - Very very minor detail that i noticed, but I can see it being cramped in the picnic like table inside the glass room to the right. It's a nice concept, but I'm not sure how patrons would maneuver around if someone were to need to go to to the bathroom and dishes were to be served. Other than this, I can't think of anything else.   Tip - I didn't have to make a reservation the first time I came, since they had plenty of tables free. Parking is a little hard. Other than street parking or an alternative mode of transportation, it's better parking in the neighborhoods if you go a little further out.

zbzbnz43wCXFCj9b211HHg.review_text: This place is a perfect spot to have dinner and hang out with friends. The interior is beautiful and nicely decorated. The ambience is a bit loud. The service was good, but the food was just okay for me. We ordered a lot starting with an appetizer, grilled, sashimi, fried, etc. I like the asari miso. It has seaweeds and manila clams, which is a little different compare to plain ol' miso soup. I like all the food that we ordered, but it got too salty for me after awhile. My man loves the pork belly so much, so I think it's an A- for him.

WF1o6AyXm6-NovD5dFnMOg.review_text: Izakaya Kou is a beautifully redesigned space that remains honest to it's shell. Clean, refined and translucent.  Our group reserved one of the private rooms which comfortably sat 10. Soft mats lined the table and tatami flooring transitioned you into the space.  The menu is diverse and rich. Traditional Japanese items are crafted with a modern light to product gorgeous pieces for the table.  The sashimi plates came with deep cuts of fresh fish with a fair selection of choice items. Each slice is decadent and they are generous with portions.  Tofu temptation and the kalbi tempura are the highlights. Each dish is crafted with elegance and the flavor pounds away at your guilt. While the bites go quick, it's absolutely worth ordering more.  Lower Fillmore: A culinary zone that seems to be moving on up and continuing the trend of ambitious yet humble food that is here to stay.

9uYtxCQ4y_2j_8ldgsmRaQ.review_text: Snappy service. Host gave us free drinks because we had to wait for our reservation. Good ambience and decor.   Pricing was very reasonable for good quality product.   Side rooms for traditional Japanese dining were a good touch.

n-UhY5NO70Q1FPpO_hSn8A.review_text: I loved every dish that I ordered except for the sake onigirl. For $8, the portions were so small and the rice was too hard. Maybe I came on a bad night? Oh well.

exygIMUwWiMg8HU4L_lNIw.review_text: First time there tonight. No reservation, seated immediately. Menu is quite extensive, and is effectively Asian fusion in nature. A bunch of sushi, skewers, fried options plus standard Japanese faire.  We shared a bottle of sake, some beer, miso soup and then ate:  - Sea urchin with poached egg  - Bacon wrapped mushrooms - Miso glazed black cod - Scallop gratin  The best was probably the fish which was perfect cooked, delicate and nicely flavored. The sea urchin was small but very tasty. Difficult to share. The scallop gratin was delicious too.   What really stood out to be honest though was the service. The waiter / maitre d' walked us through his favorite choices which we ended up ordering, and even steered us away from some dishes that he thought weren't as good as described. Additionally due to an extended wait for our final course, he brought us 2 free glasses of sake which were delicious.  Will certainly return...not as expensive as expected either.

5n_dkk0dEHFSNIJN5AMmvw.review_text: Cool spot to grab some sake or shochu, engage in some conversation in a lively (but not overly loud) environment. The izakaya-style food and appetizers are solid - not the best Japanese I've ever had, but certainly appropriate for a casual bar atmosphere.  I would say that it's fairly authentic, except that most of the staff is Korean. Not complaining (the waitresses are friendly and cute), but just sayin'

wVZwqj_85525t4URtCDvig.review_text: This place is absolutely delicious! Went here on a date as well as on a girls night out and had a wonderful time on both. It's a great place to go for a special night out. I have only been here twice but I already have a handful of favorite dishes! If you go you must get the Kyokou Mori which is incredibly simple and fresh. I could easily eat 5 plates of these because I am obsessed with the spicy ponzu sauce that it comes in. I could dip.... Everything in that. The Dengaku Miso is also a winner because of its deep and complex flavors. This is definitely much more savory and what I would consider to be a comfort dish.   In addition to all of the wonderful flavors these dishes have to offer the chefs also do an amazing job with presentation. I was very impressed after both visits.  Make sure to make a reservation a few days in advance- especially if you are planning a weekend visit because this place is always poppin.

gji92ao5NAIrb3akKyqTZQ.review_text: Came here for a Yelp event, thank you!! I'm vegetarian, so my review is fairly biased. The atmosphere is great, and I'm a big fan of the neighborhood so I'll definitely be back for drinks + snacks. When it comes to veg. options, they are limited and fairly heavy (if you want more than a salad). The squash croquette is good, but as I just mentioned, really really heavy.

EVPX7KTQyyh-k15YiNfSdg.review_text: We had big expectation when we booked this restaurant. But it turned out to be just OK.  The dishes we liked were their Udon, uni with broiled egg and grilled black cod. Udon and uni was excellent. The cod was really tasty but too small for that price. The atmosphere was OK but too noisy for us. Worst was their seaweed salad. It was just normal seaweed salad you could find in any Asian supermarket put in a fancy plate. Totally not worth it.

1nN4RNJrMSbQJHeyPUvAbQ.review_text: My sister introduced this new izakaya to me and said we should try it. Where should I start first?   Ambiance #1: I love this word and I always want to check out a restaurant for it's vibe. Do I see myself going even just for a drink? Do I WANT to bring friends there? Is it worth recommending on YELP? For here? Absolutely.   It's easy to find and people are always standing at the greeting guests. Perhaps it's their new business procedure before they get super busy, but having a good first impression is always a bonus. The manager stood at the door with a server, and as you walk in, the server readily walks you to your table.   Ambiance #2: I love the openness of the restaurant. There are tables down the center of the restaurant, sushi bar to the right, and as usual, tatami styled private rooms to the left. Each room can be opened for bigger parties, otherwise become three rooms of eight. Dim lighting and beautiful artwork.   Service: I only have to say three words: friendly, knowledgeable, and quick. I love it when servers can tell me what's good (not just because they work there), their favorites, highly recommended items, and also recommend drinks (sake in this case). I dislike when I ask a question and an answer like "they're all good" comes out. It actually makes me question the food.   Food: Can I say WOW?!! Yes. Yes I can. Presentation, originality yet creative, and taste. I'm not a professional food critique, but their dishes are how I see them in Japan and how I remember dishes tasting in Japan. For eight people,  we have about 20 or so dishes and many of them were portioned for at least the number of people present. They were very generous. Photos have yet to be posted, but stay tune! You'll know what I mean after I post them.  There's much to be said, but sometimes tasting it is better than just reading a review. Try it if you haven't and definitely reserve for parties larger than four.

tfeWk9oe8SpJz4ptH0VSqA.review_text: Great aesthetic, felt like I was back in Tokyo. That said, the food was not memorable as the flavours never popped for me. The waitress was great navigating us away from dishes that weren't going to stay on the menu. We ended up eating a variety of everything from fried beef, squid, chicken to grilled egg plant and chicken, to various sashimi and sushi rolls. The ramen was okay, but the clam miso seemed to be the winner. This place could be a great, but they need to kick up the flavour.

bFBQgg7cH_HA36RFGZYXOw.review_text: Absolutely well prepared great food! Everything we have ordered has been great! Also love their sake selection. Recommend the tasting flight. I lost my phone there once, and the next day got it back. They even charged the phone for me! My only one wish is the dish size could be bigger. They are almost bite size.
