We had to order a lot of dishes every time and the bill gets expensive quick. I think the current 2$ signs is not accurate. More like 3 $'s. The ambiance is also great. Love the large tables they have.

LrTJPD0wO8L_zBbWwzbirg.review_text: Izakaya is such a wonderful thing when done right. Not sure that this fully qualifies as Izakaya in the strictest definitions, as there are some modern twists and fusion happening here (not a bad thing at all). Regardless, this hit some great notes with us and was one of the more enjoyable meals we've had out in a while...   We hit Izakaya hard and had too many things to list here, but some quick high points:   - Yakitori - Basically the whole section of the menu is worth getting. There were some stand  outs (Ebi, Kurobota Black Sausage, Shishito), but in general everything was as it should be (though the chicken and pork were a tad under seasoned for my taste).   - Sashimi - No complaints here; Tasted great and seemed to be high quality fish.   - Beer/wine - As it should be, inexpensive and plentiful. They aren't charging premiums here for alcohol ($25 bucks for a bottle of Cune, and $18 for a pitcher of Sapporo), which is great especially in SF.   - Service - Excellent service, friendly waitress, lots of great recommendations. Well done.  - Ambience - Warm, aesthetically pleasing, and really just a fun place to be.   I could go on and on. The point is, I wish I could have eaten more. With all the booze and food (three big rounds of dishes), we spent two hours of happiness there, and I think it came to $174 for 4 people. A bargain given what we've paid elsewhere for less food and less fun.   I will be going back to Izakaya Kou, and will maybe rent one of their Tatami rooms as they look like a lot of fun.   Kampai!

DTw_x7mz1mIwak6Pa_Ds3A.review_text: Nice ambience and decor. Service is friendly but spotty. Food is good, but not spectacular. Portions are on the smaller side which is a plus if you like to sample a few different things.

6pl4HxA6N1eVLf5f3SxnuQ.review_text: Breaking my rule again of only reviewing a place after one visit. For those that don't follow me, one of the reasons my reviews are better than yours is that I review a place after several visits and after trying many things. I have a more accurate assessment of a place rather than that douche who goes to a place, only orders orders one thing and then writes a review like he's an expert. Fuck those YELP reviews!   Anyways, me and the GF ordered:  Spicy tuna roll (ok) Dragon roll (great) Lizard Eye (outstanding) Corn cheese gratin (simple, great) Kurabuta sausage (meh, essentially a hot dog. Good with the rice and corn together though) Beef tataki (disappointing but still ok) Side rice Fried green tea ice cream (poor) 1 beer, 1 soda  It was around $75 +$15tip. $90 total, no wait for the table (Saturday around 10pm) and out in about an hour, full enough. I think that's all pretty good. Will definitely be back!

s1MgWqFhSw3vfS-POOF6AA.review_text: Chose this restaurant for my husband's birthday dinner based on yelp reviews and accessibility to making reservations via opentable.   I actually booked a table for 7 only to find out 20 minutes before our seating that 2 people had cancelled. I walked up to the host to let them know our part had shrunk from 7 to 5 people and he was only too happy to adjust our reservation and we actually scored a tatami room. No drama, no attitude.   We made it time to order a few happy hour deals, which was great. They have a great deal on 300 ml bottles of sake, buy one at happy hour price and get the second for $1!   The menu is diverse without being confusing and each dish is prepared thoughtfully and with care. I love, love, loved the maguro sashimi presentation and the pork belly was heaven. They have an amazing, sweet and savory eringi mushroom prepared teppanyaki style, as well.   Our server was gracious, attentive, and accommodating and was quick to offer suggestions that really helped make our dinner experience special. While the tatami rooms had a max time of 3 hours, the restaurant did not rush us or make us feel that we had a time limit.  We're looking forward to coming back for more on our next trip up to SF.

aP523nJ5B4xnvqLrLs0gZA.review_text: My wife and I had dinner here at 7pm on Thursday night, we made a reservation through OpenTable.  On arrival, the host practically greeted us by name.  We were seated quickly in the main room.  The ambiance was comfortable and noise level reasonable.    We ordered the Kou Sashimi (salmon, hawaiian big eye tuna, yellowtail), Frisco Roll (spicy hawaiian big eye tuna roll topped w/salmon, avocado & unagi glaze), Kaki Fry (fried oyster) and Kurobuta (black pork) and Gyoza (fried pork potsticker).  Everything was fantastic.    The service was equally stellar.  We were always attended to with smiles.  Just a great overall experience both in terms of food, service and ambiance.  Would definitely come here again.

lq_XQWEb6ZKPWMvWnhp4oA.review_text: Stayed at a hotel in Japantown, and was looking for a great place to eat. Saw some reviews, and decided to eat here. Absolutely delicious with a great decor. Surprisingly very reasonable prices (I expected higher costs when I saw the inside). Portions were a little on the small side, so you will want to order at least 2-3 dishes per person. Wonderful service. You won't be disappointed.

gK8N0apndDn7P26_zGuxBw.review_text: So good! Great atmosphere. Great food. Great service.   Recommend the poke and volcano roll

KUusL15g7gVmPO7_XRp8cQ.review_text: Why is this place doing yakitori when its not even their specialty? Could not believe it when my under seasoned chicken skewer was over cooked! Really haven't had yakitori this bad in awhile.   The "chef specialty" - hamachi carpaccio was not fresh. we did not finish it.   With that said, their sea urchin onsen egg was delightful. The Kabocha croquette was huge but delicious. Cheese corn was yummy though it was screaming for some carbs to soak up the garlic butter.. maybe a small japanese pizza would do the trick. Izakaya Kou should take notes from the Vancouver izakayas.   All in all, this izakaya has potential but may need to cut down on the extensive menu, scrap the yakitori category if it cannot be up to par and focus on just having the items that shine!   ** They do serve Dassai 50 in both sizes as well as Calpico.. which is always a plus!

BxARkkmEViMDHDVddUDX0A.review_text: Decor is great...very very cool.  Dishes looked great from the menu, and they took some awesome pics of the food they were showing off on the TV.  They have a great advantage because they can take some of the run-off of people who can't get in to State Bird Provisions for walk-ins.    Kabocha Croquette: crust was way too hard, and the kabocha texture was kind of dry.  The idea of the egg in the middle was a good touch.  I wanted the Uni version, but they didn't have uni that night.    Grilled Squid: I have this at every izakaya place, but this one lacked the charred flavor I like.    Chirashi: I've never had a chirashi on a plate before, but I didn't really like the sashimi selection I got.  Meh...I get it's a weekday, but they can do better.    Grilled pork belly skewers: the highlight of the night...solid.  Short rib tempura: didn't know what to expect with this, but it was not bad.  Liked the greens to give it a change of texture and flavor.    Takoyaki: another solid dish  Potato croquettes: nice and creamy...solid  Okonomiyaki: it was ok...maybe I don't get to eat okonomiyaki that much, but I felt like it was a bit undercooked.  Presentation was solid though.  Service was ok.  Food came out pretty fast, and I felt like it could have been paced a little better, considering how small our table was.  The restaurant wasn't busy (there was only 1 other table and a few people at the bar).  Our server, with some help, delivered all the food and that was it.  Attentiveness could have been a bit better.    Anyhow, I will be back.  Hope the overall food experience will be better.

VpGATmowGR3iBkHqT-Ec2g.review_text: Authentic japanese environment, super fresh sashimi, delicious food. Pretty much one of the best japanese dining experiences you can have in the city.

fCpniKsfDPBjKagpCGHMZg.review_text: Another must-try is the tako wasabi! I'm a huge fan of the "crunch" that raw octopus has. It was mixed with a wasabi sauce that gave it an awesome kick!

M4OZcoLHydGc-M5TTE5Qpg.review_text: Writing this review after going 3 or 4 times. The biggest problem here is the service: slow, inattentive, and disinterested. The manager is excellent, and on a slower night, he is able to overcome the lackluster waitstaff, but on a busy night, he can't, and that's when the poor service really shows. On a Saturday night, no one came to our table -- and we didn't even receive water -- until the manager noticed and sent someone to our table 20 minutes later. The food is hit or miss. We tried both the seaweed and daikon salads, both of which said they included "fresh vegetables from the farmer's market" -- and they were the most disappointing salads we have ever had. Other than 3 slices of tomato under the seaweed and daikon, the description of "fresh vegetables" was totally false advertising. Many of the dishes LOOK great but don't taste as great. I asked for the beef tataki to be cooked a little more, as it was too raw for me, and the waitress didn't bother asking me how I would like it done. She grabbed my plate with a blank face and when she brought it back, it tasted exactly the same. One of the items we ordered never showed up, but it was still listed on our check. All of these lapses would have been more tolerable if the service had been friendly/attentive, and/or if the food had been so fantastic that everything else could be forgiven. But it wasn't. With the new club "Origins" next door, this restaurant will likely remain busy on weekends. If they seriously improve the service, this place has a lot of potential. I hope the owner and manager will read this and hire people who understand what good service entails.

B2-CCOGktqx1N7AGs17PnQ.review_text: Long story short: Came here for a nice dinner on NYE and the experience felt sub-par at best...  Ordered the following:   Tako Wasabi - Pretty good. No complaints and was a good appetizer.   Kabocha Croquette - Another good one. Seems like this is the specialty of the restaurant and I enjoyed this one. Basically a fried pumpkin croquette with a soft boiled egg inside.   Seafood Nagasaki Ramen - It seems that the EC here is Korean and some influences show here. This noodle dish is closer to a non-spicy "champoong" than a Japanese ramen. Although tasty, I would have ordered something else if I knew this.  Other dishes I tried were Hamachi Carpaccio (three slices of hamachi with some mint olive oil and asparagus), Beef Tataki (didn't seem like the quality of beef was there. Wasn't sure what cut they used but it wasn't as good), Sake Onigiri (really dry and the flavor wasn't there), and perhaps a few others I don't remember.  The restaurant itself is somewhat trendy and nice. The chairs were just wood seats... I wish they were put some nice cushioning there as you notice it more as the nice goes on.   It was a small restaurant and there seemed to be about 3 servers at the time... Although the servers were very nice helpful, they were scarce and hard to get a hold of. Prices were standard but I'd prefer Tanto's or Dan's in the south bay. I guess I just expected more from a 4 star restaurant in sf.

Ep51E0FyVhDO8eyZ85_4xA.review_text: Price:  A little on the pricier side, but reasonable if you consider part of the pay goes towards presentation and quality.  Food recs:  Cha Soba (cold green tea noodles in a savory iced broth),   Service:  The kitchen forgot one of our appetizers.  Only received it about 30 minutes after we finished all our other appetizers and entrees and reminded the wait staff about it.  Overall:  Very unique Japanese/Korean fusion dishes.  I would come back to try some of the other dishes.  You would not find the majority of this menu in any other restaurant.  However, some of the dishes still tasted pretty average, which is why this place gets 4 instead of 5 stars.

Le0X2J9KENoGiw9sTOsHrg.review_text: How lovely!! Like the interior, lovely presentation! pleasant atmosphere with all nice staffs there.   Will come back again!!

IlnyM_kfFD2zLNmnSmNT9g.review_text: I love izakaya style food and i want to say the dishes are all well prepared with high quality ingredients, compare to other Japanese tapas restaurants, this is at a higher price range. We made a reservation for party of 13, and were offered two tatami rooms. The bigger room fits 8-10 ppl and the smaller one can sit 6. They opened the room divider so we can still talk and pass beer around. There is a minimum charge for the small tatami room for $200 with 3 hours use of space and the larger room minimum charge is $280. Very easy to make the minimum charge since the portion is small, we made 2 orders for each dishes and ordered about 26 dishes, plus 2 pitch of beer and 2 glasses of sake, the bill came out to be around $530. Our waitress is super sweet, she gave us suggestions of wut to get and also suggest wut not to order. some highlights:  Uni Onsen Tamago: soft boiled egg with uni (interesting taste) Kabocha croquette: biled egg inside of a pumpkin puff ( must order, soooo good!) Hamachi carpaccio Sashimi special: very fresh Okonomiyaki: japanese style pancake (delicious!) Tako Yaki All the rolls are good, my favor: Volcano - depp fried shrimp with tuna Kalbi Tempura: short rib with sesame ponzu  Dessert: green tea cheesecake with lavender ice cream (Ummm, heaven...)  Tempura green tea ice cream =)))

gTDp5QNtHKeAE5LcCs2zFg.review_text: Kou has there ambience and presentation down. The dengaku miso eggplant dish is perfection. Their sashimi is mouth watering and the cuts they serve are shear beauty.  Very snappy service and generally you can find parking. pricing is a bit steep but if your looking for a treat for a date or a friend this is it.

yhExkeiKiON1kwcv7XSciQ.review_text: Pretty good! Small portions though. I had fried tofu, book choi, and a side of rice, and my sister had California rolls. The tofu was delicious; soft, in wonderful sweet tangy tempura sauce, wrapped in a crunchy mint leaf and topped with fresh ginger! Only problem : all I got was THREE of these babies, and they were 7$. The bok choi was delicious, crunchy juicy, garlicky... Great (5$). And I put my tempura sauce on my rice which was a good decision.   For dessert we had tempura battered green tea ice cream, it was AMaZeBALLs. But again small, and 6$ :/ for one scoop! :/   Oh well. Overall a good dining experience, and if I was wealthy I probably would've enjoyed it a little more. But everything was pretty, the plating was nice, the ambience of the restaurant was nice, nice nice.   And the service was A+, they were a bit busy but the waiter and waitress were very attentive to all their customers, and our water was always filled, and our plates very quickly cleared.

kug4uKJJ0tUBAe-E4SlrPg.review_text: Accidentally found this place while walking around in Japantown. trying to find a decent sushi place. this one is absolutely amazing!!  The fish Don is a must try and also the tempura ice cream.   The sashimi is very fresh and a good collection so sake

_N8uvmbF6A8nltSeIQeHoQ.review_text: I went here during a very busy dinner hour. The place was packed and this delayed the service quite a bit; however, the waiter showed absolutely NO sign of stress and kept smiling and gave us sincere apologies for the delay. It was obvious how popular the restaurant was and the staff was working so hard. When we did get our food, it was so fresh, full of flavor, and definitely an extremely pleasurable experience.  The decor is natural, clean, and very hip. There are regular table and chairs and there are private eating areas where the seating is more traditional tatami style that can accommodate larger parties.   I will definitely be back!

qiHItri5qNyG7Zz1ycEQpw.review_text: Such a unique Japanese place. Everything from the classic sushi rolls to the interesting twists were delicious, fresh, and intersting. Their spicy tuna roll melted in my mouth, while their caterpillar roll was vibrant and flavorful. I liked how comforting the pumpkin and egg croquette was, but it was a little too close to a scotch egg and the texture was a bit strange (maybe with the proportions of pumpkin to egg). It wasn't enough to deter me from coming back, mostly because the tempura short ribs were lovely, and I could have ordered the pan fried pork potstickers 3 times over. Nice place!

kUsgpVZPCeq7laaK9cg_Iw.review_text: Great decor, but the foood... Tastes very Korean and really not as good as I hoped. Gave it a chance but really the ramen, pork belly and Kalbi tempura were all cheap imitations of Korean food at a "Izakaya". Decoration 5 stars, service decent, but food... Sadly lacking with large price tags.

BzLUyHSJrl-lUVWw9rqlvQ.review_text: 2.5 stars rounded up to 3 stars.  Last night we headed for a late night Izakaya dinner in the City. We got there at 9:45 pm no reservations only two other couples waiting in front of us. The host was super nice and the 15 minute wait was just enough time to peruse the menu. The interior decor is very interesting, modern industrial meets old Asian wood. The location is terrific right on the corner of Geary and Fillmore. The parking gods saved me a parking spot on the street a block away.   Our table came up and we sat down. Our waitress was excellent and attentive. We had plenty of time to make our menu decisions. The first three items we wanted were not available because they ran out of Uni. The waitress offered to substitute ikura salmon roe in the tofu temptation in stead of Uni. Hummmmm..... If several menu items are dependent on Uni as a ingredient and run out then on a Friday night at 9:45 pm  and you are open till midnight "The Kitchen Screwed Up!" The restaurant is within yelling distance of the Japan Town Center. I am sure that with all the Japanese Markets and other Japanese establishments within a couple of thousand feet than at 5 pm before they opened last night some one would have procured some more Uni. No excuse for running out half way through your dinner service.   Advise get hooked up with a Uni distributor like Maru Hide out of Gardena, CA and get enough for your dinner service.   The menu printed "no substitutions" then why are you substituting menu ingredients?  Since having Yelp and bookmarking certain restaurants I have kept the underwhelming meals because of the food to a minimum.   The Kuruma Ebi Zuke $12 was raw shrimp marinated in some sort of terriyaki mirin with some chili powder sprinkled on it. The shrimp was dark brown and limp it tasted as bad as it was visually unappealing. Terrible!  Hotate Gratin (3) $9 was less then a mouth full for the whole plate.  Asari Sakamushi $10 clam and sake soup came out luke warm.  The three items that were good were The frosty cold Kirin draft beer, the Buta Toto, and the Sea Bass Sashimi.  The front of the house has its act together, the back of the house ( kitchen) is a mess.   Overall underwhelming !!!

Vquexp-WD-k5mxPZmS2IzA.review_text: Should not have bothered with making a res prior to arrival. Not knowing the restaurant we hoped by reserving that we'd have a decent place to sit. Quite the contrary. They put us in the worst possible location where we saw the back side of the kitchen and prep area (ie. trash cans, ,etc.) Once we saw how bad the seats were, we asked if we could sit in any of the open tables (there were tons!!) that were better situated for 4 but we were told we've have to spend over $200. We'd actually have been inclined to doing this but what a rude way to introduce 4 new potential guests? We sat in the horrible location while other tables all remained empty. In the end we did rack up a bill of over $200 but it was the principal of the matter. We will certainly NEVER return to this restaurant and would recommend you pick other sushi places that are simply better. The only good thing about the bad seats and not-so-great sushi was the beautiful presentation of less-than-ideal-quality food.

d3uP9ZeJRGROx9ZaHjPxrQ.review_text: Went here on opening day and I give it 5 stars. The staff was friendly and the interior decor is very classy yet modern. Having been to Japan, they did a good job making it an authentic izakaya. The sashimis were fresh. The ramen was perfect with great tasting broth. The yakitori was perfectly grilled. All perfect. Highly recommended for a date or a relaxing place for a group of friends or a family outing. 5 stars for sure. A must visit.

67CMefWLwKcz3FHPR6PIaQ.review_text: Loved this place! Not really your traditional japanese restaurant so I wouldn't come here if that's what you are expecting.  It's very modern and the vibe is hoighty toighty but it was forgivable because of the great quality and innovative dishes. I had THE best croquette of my life here. It was a pumpkin croquette with a hard boiled egg in the middle and it was pretty great. The portions are pretty small but share it like tapas with a few people and it's perfect. You'll find the food is much better quality here than the Japanese restaurants in the shopping center.

7SHLvPjQ-D1vIcYO2pLU5g.review_text: I had seen this change from Nan and had been meaning to try it out.  Stopped in on a Tuesday night for a few bites.  I was quite surprised with the upgraded interior and how busy it was for a Tuesday night.  The staff was very helpful with suggestions of what to order.  Food was served timely and everything we had was tasty.  My top picks are: uni onsen tamago, nagasaki ramen and the miso cod.  I'll be back.

IYgcJx84hR3cAX2tllXJcA.review_text: YUM YUM!!  Our first night in San Fran for the first time we got a late start on dinner. Walking to Fillmore street where we heard all the restaurants were we started to notice most places closed early. We walked by this one and checked the hours. Good to go. When we walked in they said they were open until 11 but this kitchen was closing in 15 mins (this was almost 10) and asked us to order quickly. We said no problem but when we sat down we were in trouble. We didn't know what a lot on the menu was. The waitress said it wasn't typical Japanese. No Fried rice bowls, no teriyaki anything, no vodka. We asked for suggestions and I picked a sushi roll I was familiar with. Being a little scared we were pleasantly surprised!  Best sushi, Yakitori  and strangely best steamed white rice we had both ever had! I had the volcano roll.  SO GOOD! The yakitori was chicken and pork. Probably some of the best tasting meat. Perfectly charred on the outside and flavorful! I wish we had something comparable back home!

LRbdiwCLK2QSClaxC6aKfA.review_text: my new favorite izakaya place in the city. Fusion izakaya at it's best. Excellent quality, super-fresh, and creative presentation. The 5 stars are for the food and the ambiance.

-89IDABrt2vnhvoCiUlVCw.review_text: They have their full menu!!  Hawaiian poke salad was on our list again, as well as their ebi avo. The poke salad was SO spicy... it was probably the spiciest thing I have ever eaten, but it was absolutely delicious. Also got a CA roll, because you can't beat real crav. We got the croquette this time (regular, not the kabocha) and oh my! My taste buds were in absolute heaven! We also got the momo skewer, which was delicious.   They also have a happy hour menu from 5-7, so we took advantage of their sake special (buy one bottle, get a 2nd for $1) and it was a steal. Luckily, we live upstairs... otherwise the walk home would have been a complete mess.  I already want to go back. I really enjoyed the introduction on the first page of their menu, it gives you some insight on Chef Nick and explains how he became the master chef he is today. **swoon**  The only thing they are missing is chawanmushi. If that was added to the menu, my heart would melt.

gwIqbXEXijQNgdESVc07hg.review_text: With the Izakayas being a rage North of the 49th Parallel it was only a matter of time before the trend caught on here in the Bay area. This is no shortage of decent Japanese food in the bay but I kind of like the Izakaya take on food here.  We booked ahead as this place does get busy.  Decent selection of beer here as well as a good Sake list.  The setup is nice though doesn't have the hustle and bustle of the other Izakayas I have experienced.  Here is what we ordered Tako Wasabi: Good as ever though its not served with Nori here (A quick chat with the server changed that and we got our nori)  Kobocha: Just right fried perfectly without being greasy. Momo: Devoid of taste. I think I will need to try another Yakitori item to hold the verdict on their Yakitori as this was a miss. Gindara: Decent as ever. Nice sweet finish and grilling was done right. Takoyaki: I am a fan of this dish. This was OK as I have had much better versions. Ebi Roll: OK nothing special. I would say 3.5 stars as we got try a good variety of food and left fulfilled.

n5kvsYIIPUVrARu0pkaazQ.review_text: I was tired, hungry and in a new city firs the first time. I needed a taste of home (Ichiza in Las Vegas is my go-to Izakaya) so Yelp led me to this restaurant.  Oh, it was like coming home- Gyu Tataki, Gyoza, and Edamame (YumYum). I tried something new as well, the Uni Onsen Tamago, which I really liked! Awesome place, Highly recommended!

iBNTPj_nGnZLVpeAzcy0lg.review_text: Just opened 6 months ago: One of the best restaurant experiences so far in San Francisco! All of their tapas are just amazing! Can highly recommend it! The best: it's not hyped yet and you can just walk in without a long line!

k9P0_aZbgIrXJXSqU17mIA.review_text: This place is very spacious for being a sushi restaurant so close to Japantown. I love the music and the ambiance! Perfect setting to just relax and enjoy good food. The service is outstanding -- we were seated right away and the food was served to our table in a fashionable and reasonable manner. I will be coming back :) The Frisco roll is delicious!!!

xko8mG7yORt6CvSiE5tHVQ.review_text: The food was delicious!  The bok choy was amazing,  flavorful and perfectly cooked. We really enjoyed the  tako yaki,  the hotate yaki ,  ika yaki and the pork belly. The only dish that was not well executed was the hamachi kama.  It was overcooked and dry.  Down one star because of the service.  The staff seems  nice,  but is not well trained.  They are not attentive and they  hang around the kitchen chatting rather that attending to service.  We will definitely be back.

MwIXDt9mhdnz5-ZpzRA1Eg.review_text: This is bad. It's a waste of a great location.   We went there on a Thursday evening with open table reservation at 7pm. The decor was nice, not over fancy, but comfortable and modern. We ordered a few things to start. They were really not impressive.   What did we get? - Tofu temptation: not impressive, but overall pretty decent. They ran out of uni, so replaced it with ikura (fish roe). I felt that the tofu taste was overpowering the seafood. The sauce was ok. This is the better dish that we tasted.  - Kabocha croquette: This looked very interesting, and tasted interesting. It's basically a croquette with an egg inside. It's creative, unfortunately, the flavor of the egg and the croquette don't really go together. - Hamachi Carpaccio(??? I actually don't remember which this was): very bad. Huge piece of fish, but no flavor. On the bottom was whole green onions, blanched. It was very strange. Sauce was strange too.  - Wakame salad: Exactly the same kind that you can find at Costco. I was expecting the branch looking seaweed!  After this first round, we decided there's no need to have a second round. We ended up going to a ramen place for the rest of our dinner. I will not be back again. I don't understand why they have a 4-star on Yelp!!!!

pI15RINDqpXIk5492xx7PA.review_text: Perhaps my friend and I are not suited for Izakaya joints....I thought it was just ok. If you are a fan of Izakaya, please go and sample to make an educated decision.  Definitely a nice space aesthetically, a lot of beautiful furnishings makes this feel like a good place to visit on a night out.  What we got: 1. Edamame - standard and tasty 2. Kyokoku Mori (deep fried asparagus tuna roll with garlic chips on top w/ponzu sauce and spicy sauce) - a NO GO **important to understand this is not a tempura roll, the asparagus and tuna had no battering components, it also didn't actually seem deep fried in general. I would have skipped this. 3. Sashimi - I really enjoyed my salmon sashimi, my friend seemed only partially happy with her yellowtail and monkfish 4. Spicy Tuna Roll tuna and cucumber - not worth ordering 5. Agedashi Tofu - very good! 6. Tsukemono (pickled selection of 4 veggies) - so so, nothing to get excited about

LI8xbnt7wIM0FY5oij-UCg.review_text: They have really good listing of sake and wine. Foods were awesome and the service was excellent. I really liked the little rooms that they have.

JKIkdVqAJLEXTq92gF98bA.review_text: I remember years ago, there used to be a Korean joint here that was a total disappointment.  Not only because the food wasn't that good, but because with their location, they could have been a nice addition to Fillmore.  Just like what Izakaya Kou is now! After recently reading Cherylynn N.'s review and seeing her photos, I suggested to my friend coming here for dinner.  The vibe and décor of the restaurant were terrific (warm, wood centric feel plus rooms for tatami-style dining), but it was the extensive menu that really caught my eye.  Just so many tantalizing things to get! -- SASHIMI SALAD - Assorted Sashimi and Seasonal Vegetables with Ponzu...$13 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) The salad was fine, but this dish was more about the sashimi for me.  I liked how they gave us a decent amount, but I wish they hadn't cubed the pieces so small.  The taste and freshness seemed okay, but it was hard to say for sure. -- UNI ONSEN TAMAGO - Soft Boiled Egg with Uni in KOU Sauce...$8 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) I might have missed this one had I not been looking for it after reading Cherylynn N.'s review.  The "KOU Sauce" was essentially just ponzu, but it went well with the runny yolk and the briny uni flavor.  Big fan of this one, though it's not for everyone. -- BACON ENOKI - Enoki Mushrooms Wrapped with Bacon...$5 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) I couldn't not try one of my favorite skewers!  Each piece was evenly cooked and the bacon they used had some quality to it (read: not super fatty nor skimpy in size).  Not a spectacular dish, but solid. -- BUTA TORO - Pork Belly Garnished with Scallions Drizzled With Miso Sauce...$7 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) Aside from the slightly excessive amount of scallions/green onions, I thought it was great.  The pork wasn't too fatty and there was a ton of savory flavors to it. -- SABA TATAKI - Lightly Seared Mackarel Slices with Daikon and Ponzu...$11 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) Unlike with the pork belly, the scallions were great here - a fresh element to cut through the fishiness of the mackarel.  As much as I liked that tart, "seafoody" flavor though, I definitely wouldn't recommend ordering this on a hot date... -- TAKOYAKI - Fried Octopus Balls, Scallions, and Bonito Flakes...$7 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) Not as good as the ones I had in Japan, but one of the better ones I've had here.  Each piece had a good amount of octopus and it wasn't over dressed/soggy. -- SPICY TUNA ROLL - Tuna and Cucumber in Special Spicy Sauce...$6 (yelp.com/biz_photos/izak…) I'm rather indifferent to Spicy Tuna Rolls, but my friend loves it and threw in an order.  The spciness wasn't as harsh as others I've had (which is good), but I thought the tuna could have been a little more flavorful (not so good). Much like the food, I thought the service was solid - our server was helpful with his suggestions and refilled our cups often.  However, I do have a knock with the restaurant's awkward layout.  To get to and from our table (right wall, by the front windows), we had to weave our way through the room with the semi-communial tables.  Not an issue when those seats were empty, another story when they're not. Still, despite that flaw with their set-up (it's not exactly a fatal flaw), nothing about our experience would discourage me from coming back.  And even though prices are a shade high, the taste is there.  Between the dishes I'd want again and the things I still want to try (particularly their ramen), I have plenty of reasons to come back!

N6q8UiEde4e322cBHCxWQw.review_text: This is a tough one - a new place with huge potential, which I hope the owners will manage to live up to. The beautiful interior - little nukes, wooden slide doors, chandeliers, make for a great dinner destination. I was in a couple, but if I'd go again with a group - I'd go for the take-your-shoes-off-sit-on-pillows nuke for sure.  And this is the confusing part - in such festive, creative atmosphere (and the service was really attentive, unlike other reviews claimed) - I'd like the food to be a little more inventive. It was OK, possibly even good, but two weeks after I've been there I can't quite remember what we had. The man mentioned, however, that's it's a lot of sushi for the price of a roll. Hopefully soon it will be MEMORABLE sushi!

pHUAZ53qwA_ka07s77Q0Rg.review_text: Met up with an old friend to celebrate being adults with paychecks and decided to start our night here.  We were looking for some place casual, hip, and because I searched for "okonomiyaki" and this place was the first one to come up.    You should note, however, that that they won't have okonomiyaki until February.  Um... :\.  Stuff happens, I guess.  Their sake collection is quite wide, with 3-5 brands for each type of Sake - nigori, junmai, ginjo, honjozo, and even shochu, which I thought was pretty neat.   We got the Sayuri ($11), which was very sweet, refreshing, and made the couple next to us think that we were gay because it's bright pink.  Later on, we got the Tozai Typhoon ($9), which was a soft, dry sake, but my palate was not trained enough to say much more.  I didn't like it as much.    As for food, it's an izakaya, which is kind of the japanese equivalent of a tapas place, so we ordered lots of small dishes to share.  We got:  Tori Karaage (fried chicken): well seasoned, but the fry coating was less textured than one usually expects.  Still delivered hot and tasty though, so no complaints. 4/5. Kabocha Croquette: BIG fried pumpkin puff with an egg inside.  Nice presentation, but overall a somewhat boring dish where neither the pumpkin nor egg flavors could come through, even eaten without sauce.  3/5. Buta Kakuni (braised pork belly): generously portioned, melt-in,your mouth pork belly.  Really tasty (if you're cool with pork belly, anyway).  5/5. 'Frisco Roll: Spicy tuna topped with salmon, avo, and una sauce.  Above average roll that wasn't overpowered by the sauce; salmon/avo topping was well prepped and shined, enhancing the dish.  Tasty.  4.5/5. Enoki mushrooms: wrapped in bacon, seasoned and charred, and finally served on skewers, this was definitely the strangest dish of the night.  While the char was appreciated, the enoki mushrooms were still a little too hard to chew through, especially when bundled together.  Not what I was expecting, but still pretty good.  3/5.    We also ordered Ikura, Saba, and Uni nigiri, which were of surprisingly good quality for the price ($5-$8 for two).  Ikura was full and juicy, the saba was chewy and fresh, and even though I've never had uni before, Kou's was very milky and delicately briny, so I'm pretty sure my friend just ruined the uni experience at at lesser sushi places.  Loved every bite.  Charge came out to around $100 including tip, which was not bad considering the city, for the ambiance, the quality, and the amount of food we ate.  I do wish that their non-booth eating area was larger so that they could seat us faster, and I also wish they had okonomiyaki, which is what I craved all along :(.  Still, I had a good time.  Definitely recommend for a business casual meeting or a date.  ps they take reservations, which I would recommend.  ---  sweet: delicious, not overpowered-by-sauce sushi.  pork belly was fantastic. bitter: definitely some "miss" dishes comparatively, wait can be long.

37scjKqPIj2o_4FFQlYCLw.review_text: One of my favorite Japanese restaurants in Japan town. Everything we ordered was satisfying. Sorry that we don't remember the funny Japanese names. We followed the highlights on yelp.  Make sure to make a reservation ahead, even you called in the afternoon for a reservation in the night will be better than wait.  For this restaurant, I prefer the dishes than the sushi.

l7m0oJpWaHaHmHXMaKWcVw.review_text: Delicious Salmon sashimi. Good happy hour.

__LzNQn6eLRaILX7SMASQQ.review_text: When I first stepped in, cute interior design, worth a try. The food is just alright... Galbi tempura is one of chef recommendation. It's a waste of that piece of Galbi... The fish is good but I can definitely get same quality of food for much cheaper. Upset that a Japanese restaurant charges me for hot tea.

0niNpv8X_2I7wIWVWl3ZyA.review_text: If I had to marry one food, it would be the noodle.  And that was before I had tried the soba variety at Izakaya Kou.  The noodle, with all its amazing varieties, combinations, sauces, broths, textures, accoutrements, is by far the greatest invention ever.  My recent obsession with Japanese noodles made my choice particularly easy.  Per the chef's recommendation, I tried the cha soba (green tea buckwheat noodle).  It was served in an icy cold, savory broth and topped with shredded onion, radish, panko (?) and nori.  Cold noodles?!  Yes, cold noodles!!  This chilly soup may not have been the obvious choice on one of the rainiest days of 2014, but it might have been the tastiest!  The noodles themselves were perfectly shaped,cut, and cooked.  Judging by the slurp-splatter left on my shirt, the walls, my chin, and my dining companions, the noodles were inhaled at record speeds, even for me!  The food here is meant to accompany your drinks, and not the other way around.   Brilliant!  Happy hour lasts until 7, during which time you can get 2 for 1 sake and really decently priced small plates.  We nibbled on pickled vegetables, octopus balls (No, not like balls balls, you nasty twin!), a tasty long roll (I forget exactly what it was now) topped with fresh salmon and tuna, before each dipping into our noodle dishes.  It was a perfect light meal for three, costing around $65 including tax and tip!  Can't beat that!  My love affair with noodles continues...

I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg.review_text: Happy Hours for the win here!  You must get their sake during happy hour, which is buy one get one for an additional dollar!  It's more fun when there is sake involved!  Do order up their Trio of Salad!  I like their Tako Wasabi as one of their salads - it is great as an opening appetizer to enlighten the palate.  Another dish that is made quite well here and is a looker on the eye, is their Kabocha Croquette!  It is drizzled with saucy decor and is a deep fried pumpkin wrapped around a runny cooked egg.  Their Pork Belly Yakitori was mediocre - not much of a spazz to it.  They have sashimi and ramen to try out!    The decor is so woody and spacious here! Service was aye okay!  A nice Izakaya place if you are looking for a trendy Japanese spot and a sufficient restaurant for a good occasion!

ORYu-cLe0SxineXThaNuYA.review_text: Izakaya Kou definitely has a lot of kinks to work out.  When we first arrived, the host took a few minutes before he even looked up at us because he was concentrating so hard on something he was working on at the cash register. We get seated and the setting is just so awkward to me as we have to walk through the kitchen to get to the area behind the private tables. The menu prices weren't terrible, but the items that came out were not as substantial as the pictures my friend posted from what I believe was their soft opening. Sadly the portions to our sashimi salad were a lot smaller and the beef tataki wasn't even rare. We ended our meal after choosing our 3rd item which was the chicken meatball skewers. I think that was our favorite item out of the three!   But what makes me go back to my first comment is what i saw overall. The couple next to us were very unhappy since the wife's food came out and she was done w/ her meal before the husband even got any of his food. While they were quite loud about the situation, it just goes to show that they need to step their game up a bit.  With so many other places around, I'm not sure if i'll be back yet. I even stayed away when they did a Yelp Event. Me turning down free food...that was a first!

gkjkDvLv4fsMP8b6-Z1d1g.review_text: Although this place isn't on the best street corner, it is some of the best sushi I have had. We walk in with a group of 6 on a Thursday at about 8pm. Seated immediately.  I order almost every nigiri and everything is fresh and delicious. My favorite was the unagi of course. The volcano roll is amazing. My friend ordered the chicken kagari and it tasted so good! Not oily and perfectly seasoned.  The bacon wrapped artichoke was too oily for my taste so not a fan.  Ended with delicious green tea tempura. Two thumbs up, will come again.

hYeZ8eAIWV2DluhxYaIUuQ.review_text: I love izakayas but they're so expensive in SF! Here's what you can expect for $90:  Hamachi carpaccio- 3 slices of hamachi  Yamakake- portion expectation? It comes in a martini glass  Pork shoulder and chicken thigh skewers- 2 per order  Cha soba- about 4 mouthfuls Okonomiyaki- about one inch thick Hawaiian Poke- SUPER SPICY. Huge portions  Overall, everything was delicious and the servers were super attentive. But definitely not a place for the voracious appetite unless you're ready to thrown down some money. Be sure to get the okonomiyaki, it's necessary if you want to feel semi full after this meal.

uERX6G3qNCmTKKd-SzFzGA.review_text: Across Geary from Japantown proper, this restaurant has a lovely interior and even better food. Especially loved the raw octopus salad (from the happy hour menu) and the egg and pumpkin croquette. Service was terrific. All around a fun satisfying dinner out.

VFxrLIlgApHIdOCrkAYIGA.review_text: I ate here for my early birthday after hitting the spa across the street. We got one of everything on the menu and everything was delicious!

PvBmRN4suldo06Kcz2-vcw.review_text: Nothing really stood out.  Sashimi was probably the best but no cooking was involved right, just sourced from the right places.  Kushiyaki was missing some aspect of Japanese flavor, like the "binchoo" or just having some salt or using tare.  None of these elements came from the yakitori.  Basically skewers were just grilled on a regular grill.  Ordered all the kurabuto/kakuni dishes.  The kakuni dish was the same as the sliced kurabuto kushiyaki without the stick, sad.  Ordered 15 plus dishes, nothing was amazing, everything was good.  Uni with onsen egg could of had more uni of course.  Asahi draft was delicious.  Oh worst was the Kou Ramen, worst ramen I've had in a long time.  Broth had absolutely no flavor, cha siu not memorable and noodles way soft.  Great service though and good prices.

SgTTg4emX7N6gCsHb5nJKQ.review_text: We had a three hour dinner here!  Really nice place and we had a private tatami room.  I didn't know what to order so I asked the waitress to decide for us.  Really great recommendations and everything was delicious!   Great to be near Kabuki Theatre too...we saw a movie right after.

ZLaCY8Hm-mzv9ZiuO5a3SQ.review_text: One star for truly awful service.  We've been here twice and both times despite making a reservation were initially only offered a seat at the bar.  We had to insist that having a reservation meant getting a table, not settling for seats at the bar. TWICE.  Both times we went.  The last visit was made worse by the attitude of the hostess, very slow service (no food on the table until 40 minutes in, no water until it had been requested THREE times).  The food is fine, but there are plenty of equally good options in the city with good or great service. Today, despite our dispute with the hostess that a reservation does NOT mean a seat at the bar--- I got an email from Open Table that we were never registered by the hostess as having kept our resy. Glad there are other great izakayas that want our business in town.

4Sixn13l0Ooa7mF_kfR3ag.review_text: The second star is only for opening jitters, this was not good.   We had some yaki udon, pumpkin gratin, fish roll, daikon salad and a bottle of sake. The sake was the best thing. Each had some nice presentation but the flavor in all of them just seemed a bit off. And by a "bit off," I mean "not tasting good."   The staff seemed new and are still learning the ropes and that's fine because it's a new joint. That sort of stuff can and should be worked out.   The decor is interesting. It's nice but I feel like it's a bit much - like they're trying too hard to be this super upscale joint when the food and service doesn't match that. Of course, if this had the type of food you find at Izakaya Sozai, I'm sure I would have thought the ambiance really worked well with the food.   A positive is that the food is priced appropriately and serving sizes are relatively large.  TL;DR: I didn't like the food but there's a small chance it could get better as they work out the kinks.

ZOG5_cnLlm_PbWqNfmsLJw.review_text: This is a nice and upscale Japanese place. The service was good but the food is just decent. We ordered the udon,agedashi tofu, pork belly, spicy tuna roll, chicken karrage, croquette, takoyaki and a few others. The sake was good according to my friends. They also only have a booster seat for my son but we didn't use it because it did not have a belt attachment. We paid $40 per person at the end of it all. There wasn't an abundance of food for that price so I would much rather go to a steakhouse or shabu place for that price.

kAyInqcd9y4TXV-5JFm47w.review_text: What a great find - well deserved five stars. Located  right next door to Social Study bar and one block away from Sundance Kabuki, this place makes for a perfect dinner spot for a date or night out with friends.  - Table was ready 10 minutes before our reservation  - Dishes we served promptly (and the volcano roll was amazing)  - The atmosphere was perfect. Causal and sophisticated at the same time, music wasn't too loud and everyone was spaced out enough so you didn't have to hear everyone else's conversation. - Insanely affordable. Just goes to show you don't have to spend an arm and a leg to have a great dinner in SF, and I will definitely be coming back.

Se6zhaEHn0lPSHgQ6q7elg.review_text: My only complaint is the portions are small but everything is so good! Sashimi was delicious!!!

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: Guilt by association. Admittedly, I was very skeptical about going to Izakaya Hashibiro Kou because I read that their sister restaurant was nearby YakiniQ, an "AYCE" Korean bbq joint that limits you to one kalbi order per a person and charges you for lettuce. WTF. Anyways, not going to even get into that. I'll just leave it at that I'm not a fan of that place so I expected the worst with this new izakaya joint. Like when Cocobang decided to open Izakaya Ninja which was an utter fail. I digress. We initially had dinner reservations at St. Vincent in the Mission which Michael Bauer had revisited and was keen on. Well, I trust Bauer as much as I trust my uncle Charlie at a seedy strip club with butt floss twerking in his face so when I heard about this new opening, I cancelled our reservations and took a leap of faith with Izakaya Kou. Pleasantly surprised was an understatement. Izakaya Kou offers some solid Japanese-Korean fusion izakaya with equally good service to match. I hope they keep it up. While not an authentic izakaya, Izakaya Kou fits in the area as can cater to the crowds at the nearby music venues (Yoshi's and The Fillmore) and/or walk-ins not wanting to wait hours to get into State Bird Provisions across the street. As with most izakaya restaurants, the menu is very extensive. Izakaya Kou has small dishes, salads, sashimi, grilled dishes, yakitori, teppan, fried dishes, soups, noodles, and rice bowls. They also have a couple of jive ass rolls and nigiri but that's like ordering fish at a steakhouse so it may be best to stick with their other items. ~ * ~F O O D~ * ~ Izakaya dishes are meant to be small so the rule of thumb is 3-4 dishes per a person and then finish with a bowl of ramen (we opted out). Expect to spend about $50-60 a person; more if you're a lush. *Kou Sashimi Combo: Maguro, Sake & Hamachi (9 pieces - $18):  bit.ly/1dss1pD *Uni Onsen Tamago: Sea Urchin w/ Hot Spring Egg ($7): bit.ly/1gDvZeI *Gindara Misozuke: Miso Black Cod ($11): bit.ly/1gDvRw3 *Buto Toro: Grilled Pork Belly ($7): bit.ly/1eUIjMa *Momo: Chicken Thigh ($5): bit.ly/1gDvMIw *Kalbi Tempura ($10): bit.ly/19hrKD0 *Kabocha Croquette: Japanese Pumpkin Wrapped Egg ($7): bit.ly/17Mg63Q The sashimi combo was surprisingly excellent; thick buttery slices of deliciousness that trump many sushi restaurants that I've been to. Even better than the beloved Gochi and Tanto (izakaya) in the South Bay. If you like Koo's spoonful of happiness (the uni & quail egg one) then you will like the uni onsen tamago which had a delectable oozing egg yolk, creamily briny uni, and a ponzu type sauce. Black cod done right, this fish was incredibly buttery and flaky with tons of umami flavor. My only gripe is I wish there was more. The buto toro had a nice lean meat to fat ratio with a delightful savory sweetness and a nice crunch from the red onions and scallions. I didn't try the momo but Mr. NSS said the grilled chicken thighs were tender and well-seasoned. Two dishes that needed improvement were the kalbi tempura and kobacha croquette. While the kalbi was very tender and robust in flavor, the pale tempura batter was soggy. Perhaps lightening the batter with some soda water and frying it a slightly higher temperature would help? The sweet kabocha with the soft boiled egg was nice combo especially with the crunchy exterior but it was sitting atop some apple-like sauce which made the dish way too sweet. It needed some heat to balance out the sweetness. ~ * ~S E R V I C E~ * ~ Considering it was the second day of their soft opening, the staff was fantastic. Everyone was very welcoming and gracious. Staff was attentive and tried to help us out with the menu and recommendations as much as they could. The owner passed by several times to make sure everything was ok and offered 10% off during their soft opening stage which is what every new restaurant should do (but they don't). ~ * ~A M B I A N C E / D E C O R~ * ~ Previously the short-lived Nan California Korean Cuisine, Izakaya Kou's designers did an spectacular job transforming the drab space into a very earthy urban space with unfinished wood walls, furnishings, living plant wall, Japanese street art on the back wall, and sleek glass encased tatami rooms. There's also counter seating available so you can overlook all the action in the kitchen. ~ * ~P A R K I N G~ * ~ Difficult street parking after 6 pm and on the weekends. The Kabuki parking garage is a block away. Izakaya is never complete without sake, shochu, or any alcohol for that matter. Thank you, waiter for the Kikushui recommendation: bit.ly/1gDM6Jn. I almost twerked my way back home. Luckily, I saved everyone's eyes and ended up at the Korean market next door drunk shopping. Came home with a bag of fish cakes. Fish cakes. *Le sigh* Happy Thirsty Thursday! *Kanpai*

eZNhFI6m07dvu1zfLfJc-g.review_text: Yakitori! Yakitori! Yakitori! They were all delicious. I don't really remember which ones I ordered to be exact because there were soooo many choices, I literally picked at random as I went down the list. Bacon wrapped anything is always good. Besides yakitori, the hamachi kama was great as well. Can't forget the okonomiyaki (pancake).  Come with enough people and get a VIP room!! Definitely call for reservations for that. Walk-ins for 2 during weekdays should be no problem.

wNQtc4ebOrojkuGOJtaR-w.review_text: Very good sushi, California roll has fresh crab meat, volcano roll was delicious. Miso soup was one of the nicest i'd ever had with fresh mushrooms. Ramen & pork gyoza were tasty. Service was great. Was jealous we didn't have a bigger party so we could eat in the private Japanese eating rooms!

ccfVsl7SZeK-2Ixc2-anuQ.review_text: Yum! Really enjoyed having dinner here.  We came in on a Tuesday night and were seated right away.  The decor and ambiance are really cool. They have larger tables sectioned off to create a more private space, which would be fun to do with a group.  Our waitress was very sweet and attentive. Our food came out quickly and with really cool presentations. The hamachi kama and sashimi samplers were really good. I loved the sashimi, each piece was so buttery and fresh tasting.  We also tried the poke salad.  This was my only disappointment of the night, it had a Korean style dressing which was way too spicy for me and took away from the flavor of the fish.  Luckily, our waitress happily offered to remove this from the bill.  i would happily recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a fun yet sophisticated spot for izakaya style dining.

d2Skpm7JrZReaYC6luk1nQ.review_text: This place has got a great ambience. The food is really tasty. I ordered the okonomiyaki which was delicious.

9fe41Vmw245Eho1PghHHKw.review_text: FANTASTIC.  First time here last weekend. My brother and I wanted some awesome fresh food prior to doing a few hours of karaoke.   Atmosphere ***** Service **** (was great, but severely slowed once became busier)  Sake selection: A+ Food: A+  Agedashi Tofu: **** Hamachi Carpaccio: ***** Frisco Roll: ***** Volcano Roll: *** Kou Sashimi Plate: ***** (super fresh fish!!)

orPR-FKHL95H756vjx2Vrw.review_text: We dined there on a Sunday evening and still had to wait for 30 mins before getting seated. They do take reservations on open table though. I'll definitely make a reservation next time.   We didn't try the sushi or the rolls. We ordered the sashimi salad, two grilled dishes (chicken skewer and the whole squid) and a few small dishes. They were all very tasty. The highlight of the meal was the Kabocha Croquette. I haven't had it in other Japanese restaurants or in Japan. So it's the first time I had it. It's a very good combination of one boiled egg wrapped with pumpkin and the whole thing was deep fried. Very yummy.  The interior design of the restaurant is also nice. The service was good too. All in all, a very good dining experience except it was pretty difficult to find parking near the restaurant.

wEqETrWwpsujK2r8ZueOFw.review_text: This place has potential to be so much better. It has a beautiful interior with a well thought out design. The location is good being right in the middle of Japantown.  My issue was with the consistency of the food. About half the things that came out were kinda blah/average and the other half were excellent. My guess is that when they were making the menu, they were trying too hard to please everyone instead of just concentrating on what they were good at.  Kabocha Croquette - Super Blah. Its basically what it sounds like. A soft boiled egg sitting inside mashed yam and then deep fried. Not that great.  Buta Toro - Somewhat better than average. Just pork belly grilled. Nothing special here.  Sake Onigiri - Way overcooked/burned on the outside with barely any salmon inside. Probably the worst dish of the night.  Uni Onsen Tamago - The best dish of the night for me. The uni was fresh and paired very well with the soft cooked egg and sauce.  Miso Black Cod - Delicious. Made perfectly and melted in our mouths.  Kalbi Tempura - Could have been a bit crispier, but otherwise was executed well.  Service was a bit lacking as they understaffed and overworked. They never brought out water and didn't ask to refill our green tea. They also forgot to bring out one of our dishes until we were about to sign the check.   But yes - this place has potential to be better.. just remove the things off the menu that are average and hire more servers. :)

UVs_7nPjqK_W_ap96IClpA.review_text: I really really really wanted to like this place but there were quite a few things that were disappointing...  The food did taste pretty good, I will give it that. I would recommend ordering the momo skewers (chicken) and the ika yaki (grilled squid) because these were my favorite dishes. We also had the chicken karaage (fried chicken pieces), kaki fry (oysters) and the tuna poki salad. The karaage was flavorful but cooked a bit too much but my bf really liked the oysters. The poki salad was actually surprisingly spicy, but there wasn't much on the plate for $12!! Definitely a rip off since the dish is mostly greens sprinkled with a few chunks of tuna =( We ended with a spicy tuna roll which was very good: big pieces and lots of yummy fish inside.   The service here was pretty bad which put a damper on the whole evening. We were seated promptly at a "communal table" but then were offered a private table which we accepted. However this table was right next to the kitchen which was kind of loud and busy.... I thought this would make it easier to flag down a waiter but boy was I wrong!! It took at least 10 minutes before we even saw our waiter, and this was after I had asked the water guy to send someone over!! Unacceptable. After we ordered I was waiting for the glass of wine to come out first since this is usually easy to pour and bring out, but it didn't come until almost all our food had been served!! What?! My bf had to ask after the wine as well, otherwise I would have received it AFTER we had finished our meal -____-   The food was brought out pretty quick but the waiters pretty much just bring the food to your table and are not very knowledgeable in regards to the menu (my bf asked how many pieces were in the spicy tuna roll and the guy had to go to the kitchen to check.... I would think that was pretty basic information....) Overall most of the food was pretty good but it was PRICEY and the service was SUBPAR =( I would think twice about spending my money here.

97UvRHbgcA8NQL8YKmun2g.review_text: Restaurant had a nice vibe. Portions were a little small but tasty. The wasabi tuna was my favorite, black cod was tasty and tender, sashimi is also fresh . Sapporo on tap

bOPFDhX5R5CUBgr2wh7Jfw.review_text: We went to dine at this restaurant. The manager brought us a bottle of water. We all drank it and later find out a cloud of mold at the bottom of the bottle!!! Disgusting!!! And we all drank the water before we find out!! Never have this terrible experience before!!

Ey4-_7UQrWXBASoRtNOwXg.review_text: Good food and easy price. Also geeat service. One of very fine japanese style restaurant.

WUn82-t99wHTsNdRkaVkZg.review_text: Love this place, if you are a bigger party book one of the tatami rooms and have true experience of eating in a Japanese restaurant. Frisco rolls are my favorite, but everything tastes quite amazing. The service can be slower at times but you'll forget it as soon as the food arrives.

r8YrTMjERM32vGUHfAw6Zw.review_text: Service 5/5 Kou sashimi 5/5 Pancake looking dish with veggies bacon in it 5/5 Soba 5/5 Fried oysters 3.5/5 but all my friends thought it was a 5/5 (I don't like fried food) Takoyaki 3.5/5 nothing special  Japanese sausage 2/5  Price was $30/person including tip. Atmosphere was great. They have the private rooms Restrooms are super clean Id go back!

OjbTRKAhC48eDNvEe3AcrA.review_text: It's hard to really see that the food lacks top quality when the hip, modern, LA-like decor of this restaurant makes it look so nice and aesthetically pleasing.   I'm obsessed with the interior of this restaurant. Everything from the long group tables to bar seating to two-person tables and the Japanese rooms where you take off your shoes and sit on the floor. The rich, wooden look of this place. Overall, this looks like a very quality, hip restaurant, but I was disappointed that the food wasn't matching the level of the design of the restaurant.   Overall, this place is more of a Korean-Japanese fusion style restaurant. Some Korean influences in the food which was unique and interesting.  My boyfriend and I love izakaya/tapas types of restaurants. I love upscale, hip restaurants so he thought this place would be great! He came here before and enjoyed it that he took me again this time around, but he was frustrated that the food was not of same quality as last time he came. Maybe we came on an off day?  We ordered 6 variety of plates from the menu (My prices are approx guesses from what I briefly remember) I think we kept ordering more because we were in disbelief of how disappointing our food was.:   -Chirashi bowl - About $16-$18 I think?- The rice was alright. The sashimi/cuts of fish were good, but the quality of the fish wasn't the best. There was even some salmon skin on our salmon. We've never seen that, never. And salmon (which is supposed to be the fattiest, hence one of the butteriest/smoothest fish was actually the chewiest, yuck) The other fish tasted fresh and clean!  -Pork belly- About $10- This was sooo good. Good, thick cut. Melt-in-your-mouth pork that falls apart once your tongue hits it... It was sitting in a delicious soupy sauce.  -Mushroom wrapped in bacon- About $8-Bacon was cooked well..This was good, but tasted a bit burnt (because of the mushrooms) that I couldn't really taste anything else. Most izakaya places know how to grill without the burnt tastes.   -Fried asparagus rolled in tuna with garlic chips - About $9-This was good, but it came out with the garlic chips so we had to ask for it a few times. When it came out, it wasn't even a garlic chip, but rather a few raw garlic shavings. So disappointed. The tuna was fresh and good, but the asparagus did not seem fried, but seemed raw. Was a bit sad because I wanted to try something fried.   -Poke salad - About $12- They should rename it to salad with bits of poke because there were honestly 6 pieces of itsy bitsy poke pieces (that were good), but still, we didn't expect to barely get any poke. Fyi, it's very spicy.  -Salmon Skin Katsu -  About $8- This tasted super fishy. I couldn't even finish it. But very nice crunchiness from the katsu and it wasn't too oily.  Overall, the aesthetics are very nice. The food was good, but a bit underwhelming at times. :( The prices are a bit steep for the small plates (normally I wouldn't mind how pricey it is if the food was awesome, but I thought for the food we did get, this place was overpriced.) Very small portions, decent food. Great service. Overall, this place is okay. I really wanted to love it, though.

rBRuie_HNzxCkMDF-ooRog.review_text: Over a week ago, on a Wed-night, I had the opportunity to dine here. I do like the modern decor, but the music that was playing was constantly jumping around to different genres, which never flowed; sounded like someone in the back couldn't make up their mind what to listen to.  There are private rooms where you have to take your shoes off before entering. This looked like a cool spot for a group dinner party.  My date and I sat in the seated dining area in front of those rooms. I think I would prefer to sit at the bar, which looked pretty cool.  We shared hamachi kama, uni sushi, hamachi and tuna sushi. Didn't like the octopus; that was slimy and truly raw; not at all like what we expected. We also had the miso cod (or was it a sea bass) it white fish that was delicious. Over all the food was pretty good.  So why only 3 stars? Well customer service was friendly when they were finally at our table. Service was painfully slow. And it was a Wed-night; not that packed. Perhaps they were short-staffed that night.

zOWReF-a4g2rPfj9y10r9Q.review_text: What's up with all the izakayas and ramen shops that popped up everywhere in the City!?  My wife and I have tried about 5 izakaya's around town, and Izakaya Kou is probably one of our favorite. Beautiful restaurant, unless you're stuck at the right side wall facing the kitchen. Sure, portion is somewhat small and but service was attentive, polite and unobtrusive. We ordered:  kabocha croquette - tasty, huge! sashimi kou - very average, will not order sushi/sashimi from here next time kurobuta pork yakitori - juicy dengaku miso eggplant - great miso sauce black cod - delicious, teeny tiny portion hamachi kama - acceptable beef tataki - too salty, 4 slices of overcooked, oversalted beef and a pile of greens buta kakuni (braised pork belly) - not too fatty but still melt in your mouth nagasaki ramen: huge bowl, generous with the vegetables and seafood.  Overall, the food was 3.5 stars, bumping it up 4 stars for the friendly and efficient service. I was well-fed and could barely walk out of the restaurant. But hey, Japantown is only one block away, so must drag self to get green tea ice-cream crepe obviously...

SYQKyn3Pox53A2IHXDV9Mg.review_text: As a table of 6 without reservations, the manager offered us the tatami room but only under the condition of spending $200 min. We offered to wait for a communal table. The manager then decides to waive the $200 minimum for the tatami room. Fair enough.  The interior is decorated beautifully and very trendy.  The first half of order which was all the seafood came out first. The hamachi mamas were overcooked and bland.  The rest of our order (5 items) was either forgotten or overlooked. Eventually we asked the waitress to cancel the order. The waitress offered to charge us 50% off the remaining order. We obliged.  After we got the check we wish we just cancelled it altogether. $300 later and we all picked up pizza from Tony's.

9kvzAuCNFpuu-Smx2Uf4FQ.review_text: First time of taking my shoes off at a restaurant. It was a unique experience. =)  Our waitress was extremely patient and helpful with the new foods I was not used to. I ordered the ramen soup. It was my first time & I loved it! The hot sake was pretty good. My boyfriend got the sushi rolls....we both have had better.   The atmosphere was very nice & quiet. Everyone was very friendly except for the big guy at the counter. Maybe bad day? But no need to be rude or grab the check out of a friends hand. Very unprofessional.   I don't think I will be back, but it was a cool experience with the shoes off & whatnot. I will now try some ramen places though! ;)

TiR1De6epQ0_-mBl8hWo5w.review_text: This one-of-a-kind Japanese restaurant is the best one I have ever been to. I have been to many Japanese restaurants in SF, LA and New York but this one really stands out. There are couple of points I need to mention here.   1. The ambiance is unique. When you walk into the restaurant you will see everything is made by wood, even the chandeliers in the private rooms look really stylish.   2. Every dish is a product of art. The dish not only tastes good, it is also well designed with beautiful layout and made with fresh ingredients.   3. The service is fantastic. The server knows the menu so well and he even recommended some off-the-menu special dishes. Goodies!!!!   My overall experience was just amazing at this restaurant last night. We stayed there from 9pm to 1am.

gds5r6Aq-Me0gpcdFGt3Hw.review_text: Awesome restaurant to have dinner before a  jazz show at Yoshi's or rock show at The Filmore or Boom Boom room; both literally walking distance away. I've been frequenting this spot since they opened.  Although it gets extremely busy on the weekends I do feel the quality of service and food is well worth it. Decor reminds me somewhat of Gonpachi in Tokyo (where they filmed the end of Kill Bill) in regards to the wooden interior and private tatami rooms, the ambiance is just as loud, lively and enjoyable.    I always get the Black Cod, Gengaku Miso (Egg Plant), Okinomiyaki and a random sake bottle. So delicious!  I always leave satiated and happy.

up_llIX0NCO2AglNA2Jiog.review_text: It's really nice inside, the food is the worst ever. My friend was convulsing over rotten sushi. Do not walk. Run. In the other direction.

WoQg9CssJ9yts7JlueDJBQ.review_text: Izakaya Kou is not the traditional Izakaya so it has limited skewer selections. However, it has a diverse menu so that everyone will definitely find something they enjoy. From udon to rolls to fun appetizers this is a great place to catch up with friends. The decor creates a warm peaceful vibe without trying too hard to look zen. Hideaway behind dark windows but open the doors and take a look! 4 stars because not necessary satisfying if you are specifically looking for Izakaya (lots of different Japanese skewers). The kabocha (squash) specialty is a must try though ;)

mEr-8BkirskBr357ysgMsQ.review_text: The yaki udon is a bit salty. My friend had salmon skin tempura and she felt that the flour layer was a little too much.

ZePYCdEAjP53MOHAtdV4nQ.review_text: The menu is varied and extensive and provides for a refreshing Japanese dining experience. The uni and egg was one of the more memorable dishes, and I also had their hamachi kama, a dish that I often order at restaurants that offer it.  The second time we visited them, we were a group of five, and we enjoyed having one of the corner rooms in the front with big windows. The service was excellent as well.  A tree grows through the floor in the main dining room, a neat aspect of the decor.  I'd definitely recommend this restaurant for Japanese food beyond the traditional sushi and main dishes. The next time we go, we will try their ramen.

E3WaRvwaDg16pSuIwVkI5w.review_text: Great meal - flavors reminded me of food I had visiting Japan.  The Hawaiian poke, Gindara (cod), hamachi carpaccio, okonomiyaki (Osaka style), and Tako yaki (octopus) were our favorites.  Wish we could've tried about 20 more dishes and will be back for the rest.  Decor was nice, and service was amazing.  Friendly and attentive, made us feel very at home.  Would recommend for a date, small group, or pretty much any excuse to eat.  Or drink - we let them pick sake for us and we loved them all.  Definitely a new favorite in SF!  Must try!

9eVsbfT2f4yAQnmowJHoyQ.review_text: I sat at the bar and ordered just small plates, because I wanted to try different things. I did not order all at once and they seemed fine with that. I didn't have to wait long for food to come out. My favorites were the takoyaki, chicken meatball yakitori, green tea soba, and spicy tuna roll. Overall the it was a nice experience...pretty quiet, nice comfortable interior and the staff was friendly and attentive.

VOmm64TvlWp1cNRb8bYFCA.review_text: I just ate at Izakaya for the first time on Friday and must say their service is amazing and the food is super tasty! I ordered the lizard eye, spicy tuna roll, cheese corn, and uni don! All were delicious! When the waiter brought out the uni don, he let me know it would be free of charge bc the chef thought the uni was a bit bitter that day. He apologized that I was not informed when I ordered. I tried it and it was nothing but delicious! I really couldn't taste the bitterness but appreciated their honesty. Definitely will be back again!

JGnqasIkGMLfSejt7mw9qQ.review_text: If you even knew.  No, really. If you even knew just HOW difficult and frustrating it is to find a quality izakaya in the Bay. I might retire from my search for a while because my meal at Izakaya Kou was so underwhelming and disappointing, I've lost all patience and hope for discovering this elusive izakaya.   The reviews sound promising and the dishes are pretty good. However, it was the nonexistent--and might I even say biased--customer service that really ruined our experience. I even noted in my reservation that my partner and I were celebrating a special occasion. Hint hint: don't be total jerks to us.   From the moment we stepped into the restaurant, I sensed disaster. My boyfriend and I stood at the entrance for nearly 10 minutes as the host completely ignored us. He was seating another customer (who was standing right next to us!), which was totally fine, but even after helping her to her table, he didn't even look at us. Not a single nod of acknowledgement. Not a "I'll be with you shortly," or "just give me a few minutes." He was fiddling with checks and menus, which again, I understand but we're potential customers. Are you trying to drive us away? Finally, after 10 minutes of this nonsense, my partner stepped up to the register and informed the man that we had reservations.   After being seated, it took forever for a waitress to come take our orders (I'll get to the food later). The dishes arrived quickly but the staff only checked on us once during our entire dinner. This would be acceptable if only the two tables next to us didn't receive extremely attentive and courteous service. Nothing stings more than seeing your fellow diners being showered with lots of attention while you're ignored and neglected. I don't want to insinuate anything but both of the tables next to us were older Caucasian couples. I noticed the majority of this restaurant was non-colored folks (it's Japantown so I was anticipating more diversity). Perhaps the staff wasn't purposely overlooking us but it sure rubbed off that way. My boyfriend and I are Asian and in our 20s. Y'all can judge this for what it is.   Now to the food. We ordered the following small plates: *Unagi Don - large piece of unagi but a tad too sweet. *Kabocha Croquette - lackluster. The molten egg yolk in the center was interesting/creative but the flavors were dull.  *Buta Toro - not sure if it's supposed to be tough and chewy, but it was like jerky. The pork was savory and tasty though. *Takoyaki - average dish but stingy with the octopus filling--too much batter and not enough meat.  *Gindara Misozuke - LOOK AT MY PHOTO. $11 FOR A TINY PIECE OF FISH?! It's basically the size of a golf ball. WTH. The taste/texture/execution does not justify this ridiculous price. I'm guessing it was for the "intricate" presentation. I've ordered the miso cod at other restaurants and the portions were not this outrageous.  We also got some beers: Asahi Black and Kawaba Weizen. The beers were the best part of our night. Just drinking our misery away! Kidding. We were still hungry after our meal but didn't want to stay a second longer at Izakaya Kou and being subjected to the terrible service while everyone around us was treated like royalty. Unfortunately it took an eternity for them to get us the check so we were stuck there. The Universe can be so cruel.   This is an upscale izakaya; don't expect the hearty and lively atmosphere characteristic of traditional izakayas. The food can pass for 3 stars but the service...I've made my case.

3G9Jkn7hKc8fmbdK8_lC8g.review_text: my experience with Izakaya Kou is based on the Yelp Elite event hosted here a couple of weeks ago. it was really generous of them to serve up more than ample amounts of food and libations to a full house of excited Yelp enthusiasts.   the space itself is really cute. it's modern and full of dark earth tones but still holds characteristic japanese elements such as tatami rooms (shoes off, sit on pillows type seating). it's a good place to bring your friends to converse over many shared small plates and light cocktails.   while i am grateful for being able to taste many of their dishes, i can't say that the food had any wow factor to it. on the plus side there are a ton of options, which is nice and accommodating to people with different flavor palates. the sashimi was of average quality and their signature dish, the kalbi tempura, wasn't particularly crispy or had anything notable to it. i did enjoy the miso black cod and the uni don though. overall i'd say that the quality, flavors and preparation of food was okay. there isn't any reason not to dine here if you're looking for a meal that is "fine." i'd say it'd be a nice go-to spot if your main concern is chatting with friends over small plates in a decent environment.

Ma_gwnVShENgTuhHNpAvyQ.review_text: So GOOD!  We were headed to Fat Angel and got put off by the $47 dollar beers, so turned to Yelp and saved the day again with this discovery.  Traditional and new style izakaya.  Adventurous options on the menu.  Huge sake selection with solid choices on tap.    Would highly recommend: Cold Soba:  Texture and broth of this noodle was on point.  Wish they strained out the ice though.  Seared Tuna Tataki:  Incredibly fresh tuna, lightly seared with some green tea garnish.  Nonkatsu Karaage:  Fried to absolute perfection with tendons attached!  Braised Pork Belly:  Probably my favorite dish of the night.  Sweet and savory all at the same time.  Served in broth with a side garnish of large grain mustard.    Everything was super fresh, with quality ingredients and perfect execution.  Service was phenomenal  Definitely affordable for the city's standards.  Bountiful variety and great ambiance.

SQ5m72npgiiVJBtSVpLH3Q.review_text: Went for the "Calm before the storm" event. This place should open next week.  The place looks great.  The food was delicious and beautifully presented.  We especially liked the black cod and some of the sashimi dishes.  The service needs a bit of ironing out but once they get that down, this place should be fantastic.

2BxtarGuZ4Rexfb8MybOLg.review_text: It's a great place to hang out with your friends, family or your love. Awesome sea food, sushi, lamam and good service! They also have something room which can give you a private space with ur friends as well as a long round table to watch chief cook food.

BMlmme_YhbcT6LFYeU3wIQ.review_text: meh. Nice redesign but the food was just mediocre. I enjoyed the previous spot, Nan, much better.

zSqv6sNrqCGe76OZgxQC9g.review_text: Great restaurant. We got a private room and ordered 16 dishes, everything came out quickly and every dish was superior. Favorites were, the kalbi and the kobocha croquet. So so good. Also, can't go wrong with a pitcher of beer and a big bottle of sake. Would definitely recommend and go again.

WSjmD3hVdnJ3sKEzrOWrZQ.review_text: Izakaya Kou, I think I love you. Really.  Wandering in to grab a bite to eat before heading off to the Fillmore, we came to this fantastic find. Unfortunately, I was so hungry, I didn't bother to take any pictures of our food. But I think you can browse through other Yelpers photographs and see each of the items devoured.  I instantly fell in love with the decor, raw wood throughout the restaurant, with tiny accents of air plants strategically placed. The atmosphere instantly put this sense of calm over you. We started off with the Maguro Tartar and the Gyoza. Simply wonderful.  The next plates that arrived were the Shiro Maguro, (melted in my mouth!) Ebi Tempura Maki Roll, (great flavor with a nice crunch) and the Buta Kakuni (pork belly goodness!)  We were sad that we were pressed for time, since we wanted to try more on the menu, and savor a dessert or two. (I'm a sucker for green tea ice cream!)  We will be back!

cS7K14kl9VZvenBiNACEqg.review_text: Pork Belly w/miso sauce is da bomb! Rare tuna w/egg over the top wasn't too shabby either.

aqU0iSjnV0swjyU4ZsxA5A.review_text: My first Yelp review ever and I am glad that I have found a place that I want to write about!
